Ottawa, February 5, 1936.

Dear Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of the voucher, with accounts attached, which you forwarded, in favour of the Principal of the Moose Factory Indian Residential School, for material and labour in carrying out repairs.

It is necessary to return the account of Revillon Freres Trading Company, Limited, as sufficient information is not given therein, regarding the quantity of lumber supplied. You should obtain another account, in triplicate, from this company, giving in detail the quantities of the various kinds of lumber and the price charged. You should have the account receipted as "Paid" by the Company, attach same to proper voucher forms, certify in the usual manner and forward to the Department, when payment will be made to the Principal for this expenditure.

A cheque to the amount of $177.87 is being forwarded to the Principal, covering payment for wages and for material supplied by Hill-Clark-Francis, Limited.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Ottawa, February 6, 1936.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your recent letter sending back an account which had been returned to you in official letter of October 25th, it is found that the account of Hill-Clark-Francis Limited has not been receipted, although the voucher which you submitted is in favour of the Principal of the Moose Factory School.

You will note from the third paragraph of official letter of October 25th that, in order to permit the Department to make payment to the Reverend Principal, the accounts must be receipted. You should, therefore, carry out our instructions in connection with this account. If the Principal has not paid the account, you should prepare a voucher in favour of Hill-Clark-Francis Limited and attach to it the enclosed accounts and forward to this office, when cheque in payment of the account will be forwarded direct to the Company.

I would point out that the first item of the account reads:

60 Pes. 1x425 Merch. J. P. 240'.

In checking this item, it is found that the Company should only have charged for 160'. The necessary change should be made on the account before it is returned.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Attention: Rev. Gilbert Thompson

Dear Sirs:

We are in receipt of your letter of February 27th, in connection with our invoice of August 28th, pointing out that our first item should have been 160 feet. On checking back to our original invoice this should have been 90 pieces, but apparently when our girls were making the copy this was put down as 60.

We are very sorry that this mistake was made, but would also like to draw to your attention that this invoice was dated August, and if your people had received these goods had checked them off they would have found that there were 90 pieces, and this should have been marked on our copy, provided that our original showed 60. No doubt they will still have a record, but this invoice is now over five months old, and should have been paid at least four months ago.

We are changing the item to 90 pieces, and trust that you will be able to trace this, and also that your cheque will be sent as soon as possible.

Yours very truly,

HILL-CLARK-FRANKLIN, LTD.

JEA/OA.

Dear Sir,-

The Department has just received from your office the account of Hill-Clark-Francois, Limited, in connection with lumber supplied to the Moose Port Indian Residential School. If you can obtain a receipt for the freight from Hill-Clark-Francois, Limited, you may attach same to a voucher and forward for payment.

Ottawa, December 4th, 1936.

Dear Canon Gould:

Recently, I had an opportunity of discussing with the Honourable, the Minister, the proposal of the Church of England to erect, at their own expense, a new building to replace the present Keene Fort Indian Residential School.

In the event of your doing so, the Minister is disposed to favourably consider providing per capita allowance for one hundred (100) pupils, if accommodation for that number is available in the new building.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]
Director of Indian Affairs.

Rev. Canon S. Gould, M.D., D.C.L., D.D.,
General Secretary, M. S. C. C.,
604 Jarvis Street,
Toronto 5, Ont.
Dr. Harold W. McGill,
Director of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA, Ont.

Dear Dr. McGill:

Your letter, dated the 4th inst., file 44-6-1, stating that my proposal to erect at the expense of the Church of England in Canada "a new building to replace the present Moose Fort Indian Residential School" was submitted by you to the Minister and that he "is disposed to favourably consider providing per capita allowances for one hundred (100) pupils, if accommodation for that number is available in the new building;" was considered by the Executive Committee of this Society at its meeting on the 16th inst.

The Executive Committee decided unanimously to proceed this summer with the erection of the building in question on the assumption that the Minister being satisfied of the accommodation provided in the new building, a further letter would be received from him definitely accepting the proposal as submitted by me to you; viz., that the provision will be made for per capita grants, at the existing rate of $200.00, for 60 additional pupils bringing the total provision up from the present number of 40 to 100; this rate to continue unchanged for a period of 10 years after we have secured an attendance of 100 pupils in the new school.

Concerning our ability to obtain 100 pupils, the Bishop of Moosonee, who knows the Anglican Indian population of the District very thoroughly and whom I consulted on the point, states in part in his reply as follows:

"Wherever I have gone during the past three years particularly, I have been besieged with requests from parents to have their children admitted to the Moose Boarding School and have been obliged to say there was no room.... So that I have not the slightest doubt that we can secure 100 pupils for the school at Moose."
Dr. Harold McGill

The Principal of the School places the number that would desire admittance to the new school from 120 to as high as 150. There is, therefore, I am convinced, no question concerning an enrollment to the capacity of the school at an early date after it is erected and open.

As you are aware, I think, Mr. Orr is now drafting a plan for us which will ensure that the dormitory space provided has the necessary subic air content conforming to the regulation of the Department.

Under these circumstances, I am assuming that the final and full agreement of the Hon'ble, the Minister, is assured and that I may proceed as soon as the plans are completed to take the steps necessary for the erection of the school during the coming summer since the large amount of materials necessary must be delivered at Moosonee for transportation over the ice before the Spring break-up.

It was further understood and agreed between us that the Department would provide the cost - seats, blackboards, etc. - of the equipment of the new classrooms; in this case to be provided for in a separate building.

Believe me,

Yours very faithfully,

S. [Signature]
General Secretary,

SG:G
January 4th, 1937.

MEMORANDUM:

Deputy Minister,

When discussing our Estimates with the Minister and yourself on the second instant, you will remember I mentioned that the Church of England had proposed that, if the pupilage at the Moose Fort Indian Residential School were increased from forty (40) to one hundred (100), the Church authorities would be prepared to erect a new building suitable for the accommodation of the increased number of pupils.

Honourable Mr. Creer expressed his willingness to favourably consider the offer of the Church of England and I so advised Canon Gould on the 4th instant.

Canon Gould replied by stating that the Church of England is prepared to proceed with the erection of a new building during the coming summer and requests that, in addition to the increased pupilage, the Department provide the children's desks, blackboards and other minor equipment for the classrooms.

At the present time the Department is allowing grant for a pupilage of 40. The rate per capita at this school is $200. Consequently, the increased per capita allowance would be $17,000. The cost of the desks, blackboards, etc., would be approximately $900.

I would recommend that Rev. Canon Gould be informed that, on the completion of the new building, grant for 100 pupils will be allowed and also that the Department will provide the desks and blackboards.

Director of Indian Affairs.
Dr. McGill,
Director of Indian Affairs,
Booth Building,
OTTAWA, Ont.

Dear Dr. McGill:

Following the receipt from Mr Orr of outline plans for the accommodation of 100 pupils in the proposed new Indian Residential School building at Moose Factory, I am having the working plans prepared by our local architects. On the completion of their work I propose to award the contracts for the large amounts of material etc.

On reading copy of my letter to you, dated the 18th inst., I note that the word "existing" in the second paragraph was inserted through a mistake and should, in consequence, be omitted.

The main building will measure 38 by 115 feet, and be three storeys in height. The wing will measure 30 by 64 feet providing space for boys recreation room, laundry, boys and girls wash rooms, on the ground floor; the whole of the second floor being devoted to classrooms.

All the lumber will be cut to size and form in a mill at South Porcupine, shipped to Moosonee and transported over the ice to Moose Factory Island. As soon as the spring thawing of the ground permits the placing of the foundations, the work of erection will proceed with great speed.

As stated in my letter, dated the 18th inst., I am interpreting your letter dated the 4th inst. to mean that on completion of a building with accommodation for "one hundred (100) pupils" departmental provision at a per capita of $200 will be made for ten years for that number. It is because
of my anxiety to exclude any possible occasion in the future
of misunderstanding on this essential point that, at the risk
of repetition, I am writing this further letter.

Failing any advice from you to the contrary, I shall
proceed as indicated above.

With every good wish for the New Year,

Believe me,

Yours very faithfully,

[Signature]

General Secretary.
EX'D.

Ottawa, January 11, 1937.

Dear Canon Gould:

I received your letter of December 31st, with reference to the new Indian residential school which the Church of England proposes to erect at Moose Factory, Ont.

On receipt of your letter of December 15th, I formally placed your request for increased pupilage and seats, blackboards, etc., before the Honourable the Minister. As yet, I have not received his reply, but expect to do so in the near future and will immediately write to you. I would suggest that you hold your plans in abeyance until you hear further from me.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]
Director of Indian Affairs.

Rev. Canon S. Gould, M.D., B.C.L., D.D.,
General Secretary,
Missionary Society of the Church of England in Canada,
604 Jarvis St.,
Toronto,
Ont.
Referring to your memorandum of the 4th instant, (file 44-6-1) regarding the proposed construction of a new building at the Moose Fort Indian Residential School, I discussed the matter with the Minister and he thinks it would be advisable to postpone any decision until we definitely know what the Estimates will be for the coming year.

C.W. Jackson,
Secretary.

Dear Dr. McGill:

Pursuant to our conversation of yesterday morning (preceded by your letter dated Dec. 4th, 1936; my letters dated Dec. 18th and 31st, 1936; your letter, dated Jan. 11th, 1937, and our conversation by long-distance telephone on the morning of January 12th, 1937) it appears to me desirable that the existing situation should be set out in writing.

The interpretation by the Executive of this Society of your letter, dated Dec. 4th, 1936, is set out so clearly in my letters dated Dec. 18th and 31st, that I do not need to do more than to quote the explicit sentence at the close of the first paragraph of the latter letter, viz; "On the completion of their work (i.e., the architects) I propose to award the contracts for the large amounts of materials, etc."

The architects work was completed and on January 7th (four days prior to the date, Jan. 11th, of your letter) the contracts in question were awarded. Our total commitments under the plan are now in the neighborhood of $30,000.00.

These actions of ours, I submit, are in direct accord with the correspondence, and I trust that we may be favoured, at an early date, with the complementary action of the Honourable the Minister.

Yours very faithfully,

[Signature]

General Secretary.
Mr Hoey,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Booth Building,
OTTAWA, Ont.

Dear Mr Hoey:

On looking into the matter, I find that the current rate of per capita grants for the Moose Factory School is $200.00, not $170.00 as stated in my conversation with you yesterday afternoon. My mistake arose from the fact that in a letter from the Assistant Secretary-Treasurer of our Indian Residential School Commission he had mistakenly quoted the lower figure; on the other hand the amounts given in the body of the letter showed that the same were made up on the basis of a per capita grant at the rate of $200.00 per annum. My letters in this connection to the Department, therefore, stand as written.

Please accept this expression of my every good wish for the success of your very important work on behalf of the Indian Wards of the Dominion.

Yours very faithfully,

[Signature]
SG:G
General Secretary.

P.S. I am sending a copy of this letter to Dr. McGill, S.G.

Dear Dr. McGill:

Enclosed please find copy of self-explanatory letter of today's date to Mr Hoey.

I cannot understand how the Assistant Secretary-Treasurer of our Indian Residential School Commission, usually a very careful man, fell into the error noted. As I have stated in my letter to Mr Hoey, the sums given in the body of his letter show that he was computing the same on the basis of a per capita grant of $200.00.

NEW BUILDINGS: The two years which elapsed since your Secretary visited this historic centre during the summer of 1935 were busy and eventful ones, and the progress made in that comparatively short time greatly exceeded his expectations. In the establishment of the full modern Newhamackett Hospital, with ten beds, two cots, and one bassinette, and in the creation of a new, three and a half storey Residential School building, with ample accommodation for 100 pupils, the Church of England in Canada has furnished unquestionable proof of her deep and practical interest in all that pertains to the highest welfare of her numerous and devoted Indian people in the Moose Factory and James Bay areas. Never once, so far as your Secretary has been able to ascertain, since the arrival of John Horden (afterwards Bishop) in 1851, has the Church of England failed to provide resources for the part of the mid-Indian field where it is surely pleasing that the good and glorious work which they began and carried on so faithfully and so long, should now be maintained and extended by their successors with the increased resources and facilities they have at their command. The double process of maintenance and extension will be vastly stabilized and accelerated through the provision of those two very necessary and very efficient buildings, and one cannot but devoutly thank God for the abundance of wisdom and help bestowed upon the General Secretary of our Society, whereby he was enabled to find a way of making this provision possible.

THE HOSPITAL: As members have already received the printed pamphlet which furnishes considerable information about the Hospital, your Secretary does not consider it necessary to make any detailed reference to it in this report.

At the time of his visit five patients were in residence, two of them having been brought from Fort George a distance of approximately 300 miles. As two more were expected to be transferred from the Hospital at Cochrane, there is ground grants for believing that the operating costs may be fully met by the usual for patients as made by the Indian Department.

For the time being, at any rate, Nurse Hockin, who is in charge, and Mrs Saucier, the House Matron, are quite sufficient to cope with the work, and additional help is not required.

The General Secretary recommends that responsibility for the Hospital be vested in the Commission, in the same way that the one at Hay River now stands, and your Secretary commends this recommendation to the members for sympathetic consideration and acceptance. It is the opinion of the General Secretary that the unification of control of
all the Society's work at this important centre, possesses advantages which should not be disregarded, and he expressed the hope that the members of the Commission would take the same view of the matter.

THE SCHOOL: The new buildings with the annex, the purpose of which will be described later, is pleasing in design, spacious in capacity and substantial in structure. The foundations rest on cement piles with wide footings, and the roofing material is asphalt shingles of the best quality. There is a neat little belfry on the apex of the tower at the east end, surmounted by a cross, and the bell itself, purchased and contributed funds from the local Indian community, has an unusually mellow tone. As the exterior of the building is painted a cream colour, with door and window frames in brown, the general effect, when viewed from a distance and against a background of green foliage, is decidedly pleasing.

THE ANNEX: At the east end of the main building (School) (which is 118 feet long by 52 feet wide) and connected therewith by a closed-in passage, there is another building, 64 feet long by 30 feet wide, which provides comfortable space on the ground floor for wash rooms for the boys and girls (each 24 feet wide by 15 feet) the laundry, the light and power plant, and a recreation room for the boys (29 feet by 15 feet.) On the upper floor it provides two well-lighted class rooms, each 30 feet by 30 feet, separated by a partition which can easily be removed when the combined space is required for an entertainment or general assembly.

Your Secretary feels confident that the detachment of the class-room work from the main school building will strongly commend itself to the members of the Commission, as it is in keeping with the policy they have been hoping for some years to have adopted at a number of the other schools under their control.

THE CHAPEL: Of all the rooms on the ground floor of the main building itself, undoubtedly the most interesting and beautiful is the one set apart, and furnished in oak, as a Chapel.

The Chapel is 50' 8" in length, 13' 4½" in width, has a Communion Table, Prayer Desk, and two chairs at the Sanctuary end, and a sufficient number of seats and kneeling boards in the nave to accommodate the staff and a capacity enrollment of pupils. The beauty and dignity of this room are greatly enriched by a window (2'4" x 1' 2") of stained glass, located on the outside wall directly opposite to the main entrance. In the four
corners of this delightfully and artistically coloured window are excellent portraits of Bishop Horden, Archbishop MacKay, Bishop Anderson, and the Rev. John East, while a panel in the lower half carries a remarkably fine reproduction of the painting of Bishop Kountze's momentous journey to the Red River. In a corresponding panel near the top of the window may be seen the lady Foundress of the W.A., as she unfolds to the Board of Management, D & F.M.S., the plans which, under Divine guidance and protection culminated in the honoured and Dominion-wide organization so well known today.

In the centre of the window appears the Saviour of the World, blessing disciples gathered out of various nations, an Indian and Eskimo included, and, in the border on either side of this central group may be seen the official monogram of the M.S.C.C. and the Winchester Cross of the "7." We who see this window are ever likely to forget it, and one can only hope and pray that all who worship in this quiet and peaceful room may receive such fresh inspiration from the record which the memorial window carries of the heroic men and women of the past, as will enable them to dedicate their own lives to similar great undertakings for Christ in the future. Fastened to the walls on either side of the memorial window, and becomingly framed are reproductions of the two paintings by Margaret T. Tarrant, one of which is entitled "LOVING SHEPHERD OF THY SHEEP," and the other "BEHOLD I SEND YOU FORTH."

Other rooms on the ground floor of the main school building are as follows:

1. Children's refectory (50' x 30')
2. Staff dining room (15'4" x 13')
3. Hall (45' x 10') with three furnaces
4. Kitchen and pantry
5. Store room, and
6. Dairy.

At either end of the first floor are spacious children's dormitories, one of which is 48' x 16' and the other 55'6" x 14'. Connecting these are two passage-ways, each 64' long by approximately 4'4" wide. On this floor is located the Principal's office (15'10" x 12'); the staff sitting room (32'3" x 16' 6"); three bed rooms, each 15'10" x 10'; a guest room of the same size; a women's wash room 15'10" x 7'5"; and a Supervisor's room 16'4" x 10'.

The Second Floor has two dormitories each 56' x 38' and two supervisor's rooms, each 13'4" x 9'.

The Attic provides a room for storing clothing; another room for general storage; a recreation room for girls (49'4" x 14'); and a sewing room 16' x 13'4".

All rooms throughout the building are well lighted and storm and screen windows are available for winter and summer use respectively.

FURNISHINGS AND EQUIPMENT. The annex will be heated by two Banner Furnaces, No. 333, made by the Galt Stove and Furnace Co., and the main school building by three Banner Furnaces, No. 328, year 1921, made by the same Company. The furnaces in the annex will burn wood, and those in the main school building wood and coal.

A Delco plant, Model No. 23-0-1, Serial No. 375902, 2500 watts, and 52 batteries will provide the light, also power to pump the water and operate the two Thor washers to be installed in the laundry.
The Water Supply is drawn from the river, with a Delco motor (Model 3747, Serial No. 026,115 volts D.C.) installed in a cement shaft on the river bank to operate the pump, and force the water through a 2" pipe to the school, a distance of some 430 feet. Due care has been given to the question of protecting the pipe against the severe frosts of winter.

There is a pressure, also a hot water tank in the laundry, a jacket heater. A table will be provided, also a stove for heating smoothing irons.

Tables and benches were available for the children's refectory, also a table for the staff dining room. Beds for the dormitories had been ordered, and there appeared to be every indication that the building would be ready for occupation by the end of the current year.

AFFILIATED BUILDINGS - such as a modern stock barn, implement shed, poultry house, pigsty, etc., will have to be provided as funds from the Department or some other source become available. The "mission house," or staff part of the old school plant will be left standing and used for storing supplies. A root-house will be covered by putting a cement basement under this building. The Principal estimates that about 50 bags of cement will be required, and your Secretary recommends that the Department be asked to provide this, and the affiliated buildings mentioned.

STOCK. The School has four good horses at present, and these are sufficient for current needs. It has four cows milking, one dry, one heifer and one bull. More cows will be required in the Spring.

THE STAFF. The numerical strength of the existing staff, if augmented by one Teacher and one Supervisor, will probably be found sufficient to handle the work of the new and larger school.

THE PRINCIPAL (Rev. Gilbert Thompson, B.A.) is a diligent and capable worker. He conducts three services each Sunday - one at 11 o'clock in the Church at Moosonee, and the other two in the Church near the School, on the Island.

THE PUPILS. The enrolment of pupils at the time of your Secretary's visit was 39, but the daily attendance at the class room was not less than 80. The non-Treaty pupils receiving classroom instruction number 25, and there are about as many Treaty Indian children from the Settlement who benefit in the same way. Rev. Louis Sampson, the Teacher, has carried on the classroom quite steadily and faithfully, but it appeared to your Secretary that his qualifications better fitted him for work amongst senior grades, and none of which are to be found at this school. He himself has keen desire to return to ministerial work and your Secretary advised him to communicate with some Bishops with a view to securing a suitable opening.

Your letter of the 16th ultimo, #44-6-5, awaited me on my return from eastern Canada a short time ago, and I sincerely regret the decision embodied therein, not to provide the fire alarm system requested for our Moose Factory School.

When making the request for this equipment as embodied in my letter of the 12th ultimo, I was under the impression that as our Society had made a capital expenditure of approximately $50,000.00 in providing the new school building at Moose Factory, and had therefore, saved your Department that amount, you would be able to help us to the comparatively slight extent indicated, in the same way that you made a grant of approximately $2,000.00 for equipment at our Aklavik School.

Further, as our Society during the past few years has provided not only the new School building at Moose Factory, but new School buildings at Fort George and Aklavik as well, at a total cost of approximately $125,000.00, the request did not, nor does it yet, appear to me to be an unreasonable one.

PRIVY COUNCIL
CANADA.

The Committee of the Privy Council have had before them a report, dated 6th April, 1938, from the Minister of Mines and Resources, stating:

That the estimates for the fiscal year 1938-39, Vote Number 169, Indian Affairs Branch, Mines and Resources, provide an amount of $34,882.00 for new works, repairs and purchase of equipment for the following Church owned Indian Residential Schools:

(a) ONTARIO:
Spanish Roman Catholic Residential School,
Moose Fort Church of England Residential School.

(b) SASKATCHEWAN:
Thunderchild Roman Catholic Residential School.

(c) ALBERTA:
Ermineskin Roman Catholic Residential School,
Grouard Roman Catholic Residential School,
Holy Angels Roman Catholic Residential School,
Joussard Roman Catholic Residential School,
St Albert Roman Catholic Residential School,
Sturgeon Lake Roman Catholic Residential School,
Vermilion Roman Catholic Residential School,
Wabasca Roman Catholic Residential School,
Wabasca Church of England Residential School,
Whitefish Lake Church of England Residential School.

(d) NORTHWEST TERRITORIES:
Aklavik Roman Catholic Residential School,
Aklavik Church of England Residential School,
Fort Resolution Roman Catholic Residential School,
Providence Mission Roman Catholic Residential School.

(e) BRITISH COLUMBIA:
Ahousaht United Church Residential School,
Cariboo Roman Catholic Residential School,
Christie Roman Catholic Residential School,
Kitselas United Church Residential School,
Port Simpson United Church Residential School,
St. Mary's Mission Roman Catholic Residential School,
Squamish Roman Catholic Residential School.
That, as these buildings are Church owned, new works, repairs and purchase of equipment constitute a grant and, therefore, the approval of Your Excellency in Council is desirable.

The Minister, therefore, recommends that approval be given for the expenditure at the above-mentioned Indian Residential Schools of the sum of $34,582.00, same to be chargeable to Vote Number 169, 1938-39, Indian Affairs Branch, Mines and Resources.

The Committee concur in the foregoing recommendation and submit the same for approval.

E. J. Lemire,
Clerk of the Privy Council.

The Honourable,
the Minister of Mines & Resources.

Loose Factory May 26th 1938

Doctor Stone,

Dear Sir,

Canon Gould is at Loose today and we went into the matter of the extra beds for the school. We agree that there would be no advantage in enlarging the building.

We now take into the school pupils with a bad family history as long as they are free from T.B., unless you do not allow us to take these children in there is no need of the extra beds, and if you do not allow us to take them in except as special pupils then we could set aside one of the dormitories for their use only.

The Ontario Government are allowing the hospital to care for halfbeeds so they are enlarging the hospital this summer—two wings of 7 beds each—enlarging the kitchen and bathroom—building a sitting room and installing another bathroom.

I would advise that if we do not have the school for the weak children, we be allowed to admit any child that is at present free from T.B.

Yours truly,

W.L. Tyrer
Dear Doctor Tyre:

From your letter of May 26 it is evident that you wish to use the residential school at Moosonee partly as a preventorium unit. My only comment is that you should watch the school carefully to see that no child remains in it who has tuberculosis in a phase which is a menace to the other children and that those children whom you describe as pupils with a bad family history should have a substantial advantage in the way of feeding, rest, and relief from exertion. If certain dormitories could be set aside for them I think it would be of advantage. This was the object of the other proposed arrangement and it will be so much the better if it can be accomplished without further building.

Yours truly,

E.L. Stone, M.D.,
Superintendent of Medical Services.

W.L. Tyre, Esq., M.D.,
Indian Agent,
Moose Factory, Ont.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

The Rev. Gilbert Thompson, B.A., Principal of our Moose Factory School, has directed the attention of our Commission to the urgent need of a duplicator, such as the one described on the enclosed sheet, and I am writing for the specific purpose of ascertaining if you could supply this item of equipment. It is my understanding that it would cost $75 complete with 24 stencils, stylus, ink, etc.

In addition to the capacity enrollment of pupils who are in residence, there is a large attendance in the classrooms of Day pupils from the surrounding settlement, and the Principal points out that the duplicator would be of great service to the teachers in their classroom work. Further, as many of our Schools keep in touch with the parents of pupils in residence, as well as with graduate pupils, by sending out a monthly letter embodying information of interest to all, the duplicator would be of very great service in more ways than one, and I sincerely hope that you may be able to find some way of providing it.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Dear Doctor Westgate:

I desire to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 17th instant in which you submit, for Departmental consideration, a request received by you for a duplicator from the Principal of the Moose Factory Indian residential school.

I hesitate to send forward to the Purchasing Department a requisition for a duplicator such as the one described on the sheet enclosed with your communication. I feel confident that a requisition for a duplicator at this price would not be acceptable to the Purchasing Division. I am, however, sending forward a requisition for a duplicator which, I feel confident, will serve the purpose Mr. Thompson has in mind. It is in use at a number of our schools and has been very satisfactory.

Yours truly,

Dear Dr. McGill:

During the discussion of this matter it was suggested and finally agreed that the best course to take would be to build a new and larger hospital and allow the present hospital building, erected in 1936, to be used as the Principal's residence. As this building is conveniently located to the new School, and would serve very well for this purpose, the Committee hoped that the arrangement would commend itself to you and to your Department.

As the existing hospital, however, must continue in operation until a new and larger one has been provided, it was unanimously agreed by the Committee that the provision of the new hospital should be undertaken by the Government.

In support of this view it was pointed out that as the Society had erected the new School at a cost of over $60,000.00, and the existing hospital at a cost of at least $7,000.00, including equipment, it should not be asked or expected to make any further large expenditure for the new larger hospital required.

I was instructed, therefore, to ask you to include in your estimates for the next fiscal year the sum of at least $10,000.00 to build the larger hospital necessary at this centre.

It was the unanimous opinion of the members of the Committee that the residence of the Principal should be provided out of Government funds, and, as the cost of materials alone, plus freight, wages, etc., for the existing hospital building amounted to not less than $5,000.00, the Government expenditure for the two buildings will be reduced by that amount.

As the Federal Government has recently given very careful attention to the question of improving the health of its Indian wards, and has voted a very considerable sum of money for this purpose, the Committee earnestly hopes that this comparatively small expenditure may be made possible next year through the provision of a hospital capable of meeting for many years to come, the medical requirements of the Indians in the Moose Factory and James Bay Settlements.

Yours very truly,

T.B.R. Westgate,
Secretary of the Commission.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

During my interview with you on the 8th instant I mentioned the urgent need of a mechanical washing machine for our school at Moose Factory, and it is my recollection that I promised to submit a request to you for some help in securing this very necessary item of equipment. The smaller washers which have been in use have been found to be inadequate, and the Principal (Rev. Gilbert Thompson, B.A.) has submitted to our Commission the following recommendation:

The J. H. Connor & Sons Ltd., Ottawa, are willing to supply a "No.1 M.W. Wood Tub Washer with counter shaft, electric motor and wringer. Capacity 36", length over all 69", height over all 66". Price $10.00."

Mr. Thompson states that "This is the smallest machine we could get if we are expected to work economically."

While I am deeply conscious of the financial difficulties confronting your Department at the present time, I am regrettably obliged to state that the Government's decision to reduce the pupilage at the Indian Residential Schools to 92.5% from January 1st of last year, has made it impossible for our Society to meet
all essential requirements such as this item of equipment out of their present income. Our difficulty has been further increased by the fact that the Society was obliged to install, at very great expense, a septic tank at this school and also to enlarge the intake pipe in connection with the water supply.

Should your Department be unable to meet the total cost of the washing machine recommended by Mr. Thompson, I would earnestly hope that you may be able to make a generous grant towards the cost of the same.

In the list of sums provided in your Estimates for the current fiscal year, and as submitted in Departmental letter of June 30th last #160-2, I note that the sum of $300 is included for general repairs and painting at this school. I had hoped that some of this amount might still be available for the purchase of the washing machine, but the Principal wrote to me in August to say that a large part of this amount had already been used, and that the painting was essential to preserve the fabric of the main school building from deteriorating.

A similar washing machine will be required for our Aklavit School but owing to lack of transportation consideration of this need may be deferred until next year.

Very kind regards,

Faithfully yours,

[Signature]

W&T JUNIOR TESTER

Chlorine feed rates are usually adjusted so that there is a slight excess of chlorine remaining after treatment is completed. This excess is referred to as "Residual Chlorine" and can be readily measured to determine that the correct amount of chlorine has been added.

When a chlorine feed rate produces a residual higher than required, chlorine is being wasted and, of course, when the residual is less than that required, the desired result will not be obtained. In the interests of economy and proper chlorination, it is essential to adjust chlorine feed rates accordingly.
Proper adjustment of chlorination to meet the seasonal changes in chlorine requirement therefore demands a simple method of determining chlorine residual quickly and with laboratory accuracy.

Because it is simple, easily and quickly performed and because it requires no special chemical or technical training, the ortho-tolidin color comparison test is widely used for this purpose. Ortho-tolidin when added to water containing residual chlorine will develop a greenish yellow or orange color. The intensity of the color developed varies with the amount of residual chlorine present.

To meet the demand for an accurate, permanently reliable, yet inexpensive device for this color test, the W&T Junior Tester is of particular advantage where chlorination will be confined to narrow residual limits and where requirements do not warrant the purchase of standards for a complete range as furnished with the W&T Comparator.

This apparatus is furnished with either of two sets of standards. For drinking water chlorination it is customary to use the standards which show residuals of 0.1 parts per million and 0.3 parts per million. For swimming pools and applications where higher residuals are usually in order, a set of color standards for 0.2 p.p.m. and 0.5 p.p.m. is furnished. With either set of standards, it is an easy matter to interpolate the results of any test.

Description

Consisting of a housing which is firmly supported on a broad base, the Tester is made of moulded plastic material which is durable, resistant to corrosion and not affected by either acids or alkalis. Two rectangular sample tubes fit into the housing, one for the sample being tested and the other for an untreated sample. By this means natural color and turbidity in the water are automatically compensated for and a true reading of residual is obtained. An even diffusion of light over the samples is assured by milk glass set in the back of the case. Non-fading, accurate color standards are built into the front of the case with the numbers which indicate the value of each standard. The standards are made of a carefully colored and accurately calibrated glass, permanently maintaining their reliability.

Operating Procedure

Clean both tubes and fill to 10 cc. mark with water to be tested.

To one tube containing sample of water, add 0.5 cc of ortho-tolidin reagent, mix thoroughly and place in center compartment of test kit. Allow maximum color to develop—which usually takes from 5 to 10 minutes.

Compare developed color in center tube with glass color standards by placing untreated sample tube first in left hand compartment and then in right hand compartment of test kit. Residual values must be estimated if the developed color lies between the two color standards.

General

Square sample tubes provided with this Tester eliminate shadow interference and all color standards are calibrated for the 13 mm. depth of liquid and the quantities of water and reagent as indicated. It is essential that the correct sample tubes and color standards are used at all times with this kit.

Before taking readings be sure that the glass color standards, the sample tubes and the frosted glass in the back of the case are clean.

Never test samples that have stood in sunlight as the color developed by ortho-tolidin will fade.

THE W&T HYPOCHLORINATOR

Chlorination of the small water supply, whether public or private, where chlorine requirements are small and supervision limited, presents a distinct problem in the field of sanitation. Today, more than 85% of the country's domestic water supply is chlorinated but in many instances small supplies have been neglected due to the lack of suitable equipment. The W & T Hypochlorinator has been specifically designed to meet this need. Small in size, easily installed and requiring a minimum of operating supervision, it offers for the small supply the efficient protection of chlorination at the lowest possible cost.

How the W&T Hypochlorinator Operates

The Hypochlorinator consists essentially of a diaphragm pump constructed of corrosion resistant material and so designed that the rate of chlorine application may be easily adjusted to properly chlorinate the water flowing through a pipe line. The fundamental operating principle is outstanding from the standpoint of design and is exclusive with W & T Hypochlorinators. It consists in the use of a balanced diaphragm with a single suction valve and single discharge valve, solution being drawn into the diaphragm chamber on the suction stroke and forced out to the point of application on the discharge stroke. On the delivery side of the diaphragm the pressure is the same as that at the point of application. On the reverse side of the diaphragm, water under full main pressure is allowed to flow into the diaphragm chamber through a suitable control or balancing valve which confines this water and balances the diaphragm between equal pressures. Pumping is accomplished by application of an intermittent impulse which causes the diaphragm to reciprocate in a manner similar to a pump piston. This principle of operation gives extraordinarily long diaphragm life because of minimum strain on the diaphragm and, in addition, allows the pump to deliver a uniform volume of solution regardless of the water pressure encountered. Control of the pump may be effected either with a small electric motor or specially designed water driven element depending upon existing conditions at the point of application. Manual or semi-automatic (automatic start and stop) operation can be used on either electric or water driven type and a third type, water meter controlled, will automatically proportion the rate of chlorine supplied to the water flow. Hence, the W & T Hypochlorinator is readily adaptable to any small water supply whether it be a steady flow, a pumped supply with automatic start and stop, or a variable flow gravity supply.
Electrically Operated Hypochlorinator

The Electrically Operated Hypochlorinator is particularly adaptable for use on small pumped water supplies operated either manually or by automatic start and stop of the pumping unit. The equipment is operated by water under pressure equal to or greater than that into which the chlorine solution is applied and operation is directed by means of a small electric motor.

Since water pressure furnishes the major part of the power needed to operate the Hypochlorinator, the electric power required is greatly reduced and the small electric motor used consumes no more than 40 watts—at ordinary rates, a cost for electricity averaging not over 6c. a day. Waste water is also reduced to a minimum and averages no more than a quarter of a gallon per minute.

Rate of chlorine application may be varied by changing the length of the pumping stroke or by the choice of either of two operating speeds, the total capacity range of the apparatus being 30 to 1. Motor and gears are entirely enclosed and operate in an oil bath—hence there is no lubrication problem.

The Electrically Operated Hypochlorinator is designed to operate on any water pressure from 5 lbs. to 125 lbs. per square inch. For pressures below 5 pounds per square inch or where negative pressure exists at the point of application, a special electrically operated unit has been designed which operates entirely on electric power and has no water connections or fittings.

Water Operated Hypochlorinator

The Water Operated Hypochlorinator uses only water pressure for operation, one flow being used to operate the balanced diaphragm and another flow controlling the operation. Since it is entirely independent of electric or external mechanical power it is particularly well adapted for emergency work, for standby or duplicate installation, or for any installation requiring a steady rate of chlorination. The equipment is operated by water under pressure equal to or greater than that into which the chlorine solution is applied, the minimum water pressure being 10 pounds per square inch and the maximum 125 pounds per square inch. By using the pilot principle of design wherein minute mechanical forces are able to operate the equipment with small quantities of water, the amount of waste water is reduced to a minimum and averages not more than one-half gallon per minute. Variation in rate of chlorine application is accomplished by changing the number of pumping strokes per minute and gives a 12 to 1 range. An important advantage of the W & T Water Operated Hypochlorinator lies in the fact that the suction stroke is extremely rapid, requiring only a small percentage of the running time and hence the rate of chlorine application is remarkably steady.

Automatic Hypochlorinator

Because of wide flow variations on small gravity water supplies, an automatic meter driven chlorinator of small capacity has long been in demand. The W & T Automatic Hypochlorinator fulfills the requirements for this type of installation in all respects. Operation is similar to the Manual Water Operated Hypochlorinator but the rate of pumping and hence the rate of chlorine application is directly controlled by a water meter installed in the main water line. Any type of meter in which a shaft turns in direct ratio to the flow of water through the meter may be used, and the chlorine applied will be at all times proportional to the water flow. Variation in treatment is accomplished by varying the length of stroke, for which purpose a control handle and dial are provided on the equipment. The accuracy of the W & T Automatic Hypochlorinator when used with small water meters is outstanding and is due to the important and exclusive principle of design wherein small mechanical power is required to activate the balanced diaphragm pump—an advantage found only in W & T equipment.

### Short Specifications for W&T Hypochlorinator

**TYPE:** The Chlorinator shall be a manually operated control of the Hypochlorinator from maximum to minimum.

**METHOD OF CONTROL:** The Chlorinator shall be activated and controlled by means of a lever mounted on the side of the tank. The lever shall be connected to the driving arm by means of a chain or other suitable means.

**METHOD OF MEASUREMENT:** The Chlorinator shall have a means of measuring the amount of chlorine delivered to the water. This may be accomplished by means of a flow meter or other suitable device.

**METHOD OF CONTROL:** (A) Manual Electrical Control: The Chlorinator shall be equipped with an electrical control system which shall be capable of controlling the operation of the Chlorinator from a distance of not more than 100 feet.

(B) Manual Water Control: The Chlorinator shall be activated and controlled by means of a lever mounted on the side of the tank. The lever shall be connected to the driving arm by means of a chain or other suitable means.

(C) Automatic Control: The Chlorinator shall be activated and controlled by means of a lever mounted on the side of the tank. The lever shall be connected to the driving arm by means of a chain or other suitable means.

**SPARE PARTS:** There shall be furnished with each Chlorinator in addition to the above parts, a spare set of diaphragm gaskets, a spare piece of hose, and a spare set of bolts and nuts.

**INSTALLATION:** The Chlorinator shall be installed under the direct supervision of a factory trained representative. The installation shall be completed within two weeks from the date of receipt of order.

Dear Dr. Orford:

By all appearances the present accommodation for school children in the Residential School is not going to be sufficient for our needs this coming term. The children of the village are coming to school in increasing numbers and we have decided that it will be necessary to reopen the building known as the old day school. This building can be converted easily into an adequate school but desks and a few furnishings are needed. I have enclosed a formal requisition which I hope meets with your approval. If you think fit it would be of considerable help if you could requisition for enough wall board to cover the ceiling. The building at present is of the very high roof variety and would take a lot of fuel to heat properly. The size of the roof or ceiling surface would be 45' by 30' and a sufficient number of 2 by 4's to be used for studding would be needed also.

Your early attention to this matter would be appreciated as time for school reopening is not far distant.

Yours faithfully,

Henry G. Cook

Dear Colonel Neary:

As you are aware, following the typhoid epidemic at the above school in the fall of 1947, Mr. A. H. Perry, Supervising Engineer, Department of National Health and Welfare, carried out a thorough investigation of conditions there and submitted a comprehensive report. I quote from this report as follows:

"Improvements - Sewage Systems, Anglican Mission

The present system of sewage disposal is entirely unsatisfactory and ever present menace to the safety of the Moose River water as well as creating a public health nuisance and menace from flies, etc., to the Indian tenting on camp ground in front of the Mission.

With the proposed construction of a new hospital imminent it would appear advisable to construct a small sewage treatment plant capable of handling the sewage from the hospital and other immediate buildings, as well as from the Anglican Mission. An Ishoff tank design would be recommended with proper disposal of the effluent away from the river and such as not to endanger the safety of the under-ground water.

It was in the local papers a few days ago that the construction of a new hospital at Moose Factory is now assured and that building operations are to start during the coming spring. I understand that this new hospital will be located on property immediately adjacent to the Bishop Horden Memorial School.

In view of the foregoing, it is requested that action be taken, as recommended by Mr. A. H. Perry, to carry the sewage from the Bishop Horden Memorial School to the sewage disposal plant provided for the new hospital.

(over)
May I suggest that approval of this request may be facilitated by the fact that we have been advised by your Deputy Minister, under date of 16th January, 1948, that provision for the purchase of this School has been made in the estimates submitted by your Department for 1948-49.

May we be advised, please, at your earliest convenience, of the action taken on this request regarding disposal of sewage from our school.

Yours sincerely,

G. R. Turner
for Acting Superintendent.
(absent on duty.)

Memorandum:

It is our intention, if funds are provided, to purchase this school from the M. S. O. C. Therefore, we are concerned over the provision of an adequate sewage disposal system. Would it be possible to install a sewage disposal system at the hospital, which would also look after our school needs.

I would appreciate your referring this matter to your engineers, if you concur in such action.

Dear Mr. Breult:

I have your 44-6-5(E.1) dated 24th September, 1948, advising me that you have no funds for paying the accounts for labour on painting forwarded you with my letter of 13th September, 1948, because you have already over-expended the $1000.00 provided in this year's estimates on sports equipment, extractor, paint and bricks.

I must say that this has come as a most unwelcome surprise because in your 44-6-5(E.1) of 5th March, 1948, you informed me that you were endeavouring to arrange for the transfer of $1000.00 from an unexpended 1947-48 appropriation at Whitefish Lake to Moose Factory to pay for the extractor and for as much paint as the balance would permit.

In your 160-2 (W.T.1) of 16th January 1948, you advised me that the sum of $2661.27 remained unexpended in your 1947-48 appropriations for Anglican Church-owned Schools—Fort George $66.14, Wabasca $83.61, Whitefish Lake $1,211.52 and Carcross $600.00, but against this was an over-expenditure of $240.17 at Aklavit. P.M., Re: Estimates for Fort Moose Factory Residential School.

Replying to your File 44-5-5 of Sept. 19, in connection with appropriations for the fiscal year 1949-50, for improvements to Fort Moose Factory school.

A short time ago I made a survey of this school, along with Mr. Monette of the Public Works Dept., and although this was only a superficial survey I would hesitate to quote an estimate as to what the cost of improvements, etc., would be were the Department to take over this school. This building is of frame structure, set up on mud sills and will require a considerable amount to repair and renovate. In making a fair guess Mr. Monette claims that this would require more than Thirty Thousand dollars, and if the school is being taken over by the Department, I would suggest that extensive repairs and alterations be held until that time.

(a) Installation of wall-mounted refrigeration would cost approximately $2,500. As this would require freezing and deodorizing unit, also cork board insulation and tar composition. The location as to where this unit will be placed and the position of same will depend largely upon the insulation costs.
(b) Water Supply
The School is situated a considerable distance from hospital site and water pipes would have to be sunk at least six feet to clear of the frost. It would require a six inch water main and a house fitted with pump to hold pressure. With the installation of water system consideration would have to be given to the setting up of plumbing fixtures, etc., at strategic points for future necessary equipment.

(b) Sewage System
Sewage system throughout school is in very poor condition and to do a proper job it may be necessary to rip this out and replace which no doubt would be a costly business. To connect sewage with hospital site would require a 10" or 12" main of vitrified tile and may involve the installation of thrasher pump. I hesitate to make an estimate on the installation of both water and sewage systems but feel that this would cost at least $16,000.

(c) Toilet for Staff
The installation of a three piece toilet, with floor added, would cost approximately $250 assuming, of course, that this can be set up adjacent to the present latrines.

(d) Fire Escape
It would not be advisable to have a fire escape of timber construction unless it were of the chute type. Letal stairs would be more appropriate and would cost very little more. An allowance of $300 Two hundred Dollars should be made for this.

(e) Insulation of Attic
Amount of Two Hundred Dollars quoted for insulation attic would be about enough for area required.

(f) Interior Painting
Estimate of Two Hundred Dollars $200 would barely cover materials for this and it is suggested that another Four Hundred Dollars $400 be added for labor.
Summary of above Estimate

(a) Walk-in Refrigerator ........................................ $2,500.
(b) Water Supply and Sewage .................................... $15,000.
(c) Bathroom for Staff ........................................... $250.
(d) Fire Escape ...................................................... $200.
(e) Insulation of Attic .............................................. $100.
(f) Interior Painting ................................................ $100.

Add for unforeseen expenditure such as repair to foundation and other buildings $5,000.

Total . . $24,150.

In the past few months I have had Loose Fort School under close observation and find that the boys are apparently running loose owing to the lack of proper educational facilities. This school has over 91 residential pupils and 35 day pupils.

I have discussed this situation with Mr. Taylor and he advises that he has neither the staff nor the school rooms to accommodate the number of pupils on a full time basis. Nearly all the children are on half day basis and I understand that this has been the practice for several years.

During my recent survey of the James Bay lands I had several complaints from the Indians claiming that their children were not receiving sufficient education for the time that they are spending at Loose Factory. The fault in this case does not lie with Mr. Taylor but is merely a case of overcrowding.

You will notice that in my Estimates I have made an allowance of Twenty Thousand Dollars for a Day School which would be incorporated with the set-up of new Indian Village which I hope to have under way next summer. The problem at Loose Fort School is that we have over 35 pupils of non-indian status and it would seem next to
impossible to eliminate these children from the privileges extended to the Indian. It has occurred to me that if we were to establish a day school on the Island we might be able to arrange a reciprocal agreement with the Provincial Government to take care of the Indian children which is out an equal amount to the Boosonee side and we could provide for the white children at this end in our School.

Superintendent of Education:

Moose Fort Residential School:

As of noon today seventy pupils were confined to bed with influenza. Some of the staff are affected and off duty. Classroom activities have been suspended. There are numerous cases of the ailment in the non-school population. The fire last Saturday destroyed a large part of the drugs necessary for treatment, but emergency supplies have been obtained.

The lay-out of the school does not lend itself to convenient isolation and care of the sick.

To begin with, the dormitories are populated well beyond the limit indicated in Departmental regulations. In the girls' dormitory there is one basin with taps and one flush toilet. In the boys' dormitory there was a like installation, but the toilet has been out of order for a long time.

Food has to be carried from the basement kitchen up two stories, and there is not, of course, a supply of trays adequate for such an emergency with the natural result that there is a good deal of inconvenience and considerable mess.

The situation affords a pathetic contrast with the infirmary at Prince Albert which has flexible accommodation for both sexes, adequate plumbing, and a convenient dispensary; also equipment and other provision for serving food at the proper temperature.

It has been in my mind for some time to recommend that the Moose Fort Residential School restrict its activities to those of a hostel, and that a separate building be provided for classroom purposes and recreational, physical and vocational training. There is a growing population on this island, both Indian and non-Indian, which already overtaxes the day school accommodation which the Moose Fort buildings can provide. Additional dormitory space is needed in the residential school where one dormitory has been converted into a third sub-standard classroom. It should be restored to its original function. Other uses could well be found for the two actual classrooms if a building of adequate size were available for school and community purposes.

C.A.F. Clark

Tentative Recommendations for a school building programme:

1. A large classroom block convenient to the Moose Fort Residential School, serving Indian and white children on the island as day pupils and Albany, Rupert House and Eastmain Anglican Indians in residence at Moose Fort.

2. A smaller classroom block at Fort George (C.E.) to serve pupils in residence from Old Factory, Fort George and points north.

3. A significant enlargement of the installation at Albany P.C. residential school to serve Albany, Attawapiskat, Winisk, Fort George and any Roman Catholic Indians on the eastern shore.

4. Adaptation of existing buildings or shelters at Attawapiskat and Rupert House with seasonal additions to the teaching staff sufficient to ensure full coverage for all eligible children. Rupert House has a small school, the community hall and an old church (C.E.).

Moose Factory, Ont.,
February 27, 1949.

Superintendent of Education,
Indian Affairs Branch:

Moose Fort Indian Residential School-
Purchase of Furnishings and Equipment:

Herewith is submitted a copy of the inventory of articles offered for sale with the prices for items as tentatively agreed upon by the Principal, the local Archdeacon, the agency Superintendent (Mr. J.S. Allan) and myself. Mr. Allan, however, was not present for the evaluating of the farm machinery and horses which are offered without, apparently, barns or buildings to house them, and their utility is on that account, at least, open to question.

Similarly, as there is little prospect of resuming the keeping of milch cows, certain items of dairy equipment appear to be surplus to requirements here.

The power plant has, I understand, already been appraised by a representative of the Department of Public Works. From what I know of electric batteries I would judge that some cells are about ready to collapse and that all will require early replacement.

The value set on the boat L.S. "Adventure" might well be the subject of further negotiation.

The X-ray equipment will likely become unnecessary here when the hospital presently under construction nearby is ready to function.

A copy of this memorandum is being furnished to Mr. Supt. Allan together with a copy of the inventory (as amended to Feb. 26th). The Principal has a copy of the inventory.

Archdeacon Clarke told me that the Church is to retain title to the barns.

C.A.F. Clark

C.A.F. Clark

This was an accumulation of fecal matter that has been deposited at the top of the river bank less than 20 feet away from the river right in the vicinity of the intake. This condition was discovered by the medical officer and subsequently rectified but illustrates the hazards to which surface sources of water supply are usually exposed.

The placement of a water supply intake in this area in relation to points of sewage discharge is of no value due to the action of the tides which reverse the flow of the river; although the Island is twelve miles from James Bay the effect of the tide is felt farther as it might happen, another twenty miles upstream from Moose Factory. The salt water contamination of the river is very slight and the effect of an incoming tide is to back up the fresh water and cause a reversal of flow. Thus, it would be quite impossible to locate a water intake upstream from any sewer outfall.

The range of the diurnal tides is from 5 to 7 feet but this may vary considerably depending on the velocity and direction of the wind. As stated previously the Mission's water intake is located in a cross-channel with reverse flows induced by either the wind or the tide or a combination of both.

BACTERIOLOGICAL ANALYSIS OF WATER

In searching through the local files of the Indian Agent only a few copies of laboratory reports could be found covering bacteriological analyses of the river water and other sources. However, other correspondence in the files revealed that other specimens had been obtained from time to time and reference was made to the high incidence of fecal contamination usually prevalent in the Moose River water.

A number of water specimens from various sources were collected by the undersigned at the time of visit and the laboratory report on these are appended to this memorandum.

ANIMAL FACTORY - ANIMAL SEWAGE

Surrounding the school building are four septic tanks. One concrete tank serving four (4) flush toilets, one steel tank serving one (1) flush toilet, one steel tank serving two (2) flush toilets and one concrete tank serving the small hospital all discharge to a common point. Laundry, sink and bathtub wastes bypass the septic tanks and also discharge to a common point.

The arrangement to dispose of the septic tank effluents and other liquid wastes was formerly a four inch sewer composed of unplanned field tile which was laid for a distance of approximately 2,000 feet into a shallow depression in the bottom of the creek. Apparently this sewer was not laid in a straight line or with sufficient slope, so in any event, its course became plugged and overflowed elsewhere. In the late fall of 1946 much of the tile was dug up and reclaimed. It was then laid in the opposite direction, easterly towards the river and new discharges just under the river bank in front of the school creating a foulness and nuisance. The effluent finds its way into a low swampy area where it mingle with the overflows from a small pond and discharges into the Moose River at a point which is only 50 feet from the water supply intake.

Thus, sewage may readily reach the water supply intake. The facts that the water supply system was being inadequately treated by chlorination, that the sewer outfall location had been changed within the past year and that the outbreak of disease had begun during this time, progressing to a total of ten cases, all combine to throw suspicion on the water supply and indicate it to be the mode of transmission of the infective organism. So far, the epidemiological work conducted has not detected an actual typhoid carrier although it is probable that a carrier has been present.

continued........
In connection with the proposed construction of an Indian Hospital (130) both preliminary bore hole reports to determine availability of water supply have already been made by Pauline Barton, Mr. Superintendent, District Engineer of Public Works. It was found that a water table existed on the Island at a distance of about 6.2 feet below the surface and that there appeared to be little danger of contamination from the river water. One test well was put down in the new hospital site but no pumping tests have yet been run nor has the work progressed far enough to have analyses made.

A new well is being dug beside the pumping house for an alternative source of supply for the school. Also a new well is being dug by the Indian Agent, which will have a small pumping system with a public tap from which Indians may draw water.

With ground water available it would appear advisable to abandon the Moose River as a source of drinking and culinary water for the Island.

Until pumping tests are run on individual wells it is not possible to say whether sufficient water would be available for all purposes. It may be that a separate system from the river for fire protection and possibly laundering, would be required.

Whether the developed wells would require treatment to render the water safe for drinking purposes could only be determined after a series of analyses, both chemical and bacteriological.

The present system of sewage disposal is entirely unsatisfactory and over present menace to the safety of the Moose River water as well as creating a public health nuisance and menace from flies, etc., to the Indian tenting on camp ground in front of the Mission.

With the proposed construction of a new hospital incinerator it would appear advisable to construct a small sewage treatment plant capable of handling the sewage from the hospital and other immediate buildings, as well as from the Anglican Missionaries. An embankment design would be recommended with proper disposal of the effluent away from the river and such as not to endanger the safety of the underground water.

GENERAL SANITATION OF SETTLEMENT

The general sanitation is very poor. Accumulations of garbage, tin cans and rubbish litter the banks in front of the settlement and are very offensive around many of the Indian houses. This condition creates excellent fly-breeding facilities with their attendant public health menace. There should be some type of garbage collection system but as this is unorganized territory in the Province of Ontario the supervision of these matters would come under the Ontario Health Department.

The absence of sewage disposal facilities for this bulk of the Indian houses has been referred to previously. It is understood that the Hudson's Bay Company is proceeding with the installation of a pumped water supply system opposite town, and a tile drainage field. The latter would be a tremendous although still primitive, if properly maintained would be sufficient to meet cases where there is no piped water under pressure available.

WATER SUPPLY RECOMMENDATIONS

1. It is recommended that the Moose River, in view of the sewage contamination known to exist, be discontinued as a source of drinking and culinary water supply for the Anglican School and that underground water in which a shallow well is now being dug be used for this purpose.

continued.........
1. Whether chlorination of the ground water from the mill would be advisable or not can only be determined after a series of bacteriological analyses.

2. For the present it is recommended that all water drawn from this river for drinking purposes should be boiled before use.

3. The river water could be used for fire protection purposes in the event there is not enough water available from the well for all purposes. Adequate precautions would have to be taken to prevent cross-contamination and two physically separate water systems would be required.

4. The existing hypochlorinator could be adapted to treat water from the new well, if required. Pipings for the water supply connection to the hypochlorinator should be changed and made direct from the pressure side of the tank. The other defects pointed out in the section dealing with the water supply should be corrected.

5. If the principle is followed of prohibiting the use of the Moose River for drinking purposes, raw or treated, and using developed ground water and wells on the Island, then sewage could be run into the river. However, this proposal would require the approval of the Ontario Health Department.

6. It is recommended that some treatment of the sewage be carried out. A single sewage treatment plant to take care of the new hospital as well as the Anglican Mission could be located in a central area. The type of treatment plant could be similar to the Rideau Health and Occupational Center (D.V.A.), near Ottawa, employing an Ishoff tank, sludge drying beds and chlorination of the effluent. The latter could be disposed of into the Moose River without nuisance.
The operator stated that the residual chlorine was measured only once a month. The river water contains a high amount of color together with organic matter and may have a relatively high and seasonal variation owing to increased vegetation coming down following spring break-up. Also there may be local variations due to contamination from sewage getting into the river above the intake. Consequently the chlorine added to the water should be tested daily for free chlorine and a continuous daily record maintained.

The comparator supplied with the hypochlorinator for testing free chlorine is of a type which is difficult for even experienced operators to read. It had not been used for some time as it was covered with dust. The operator had been using a clean test tube in making the tests. It is quite possible that a false reading may have been taken on the occasions when the tests were made, due to two causes. First the orthotolidine reagent being used was over three years old and had become discolored. This solution rapidly deteriorated after it has been prepared and should be renewed every two or three months. The river water is highly coloured and these two qualities may combine to give a color reaction even when no free chlorine is present. A bottle of freshly prepared orthotolidine was left with the operator.

The chlorine solution used to feed the hypochlorinator was being made from chloride of lime which is very unstable. As this compound contains at least from 25 to 35% free chlorine, the precipitate of small particles of inert powder frequently plug the orifice of the chlorinator thus interfering with its proper functioning. It was recommended, that a liquid solution of sodium hypochlorite be ordered, then metered down to the desired strength of approximately 0.5% for use with the chlorinator.

It may therefore be concluded that inadequate and ineffective chlorination has been provided during the past year at least, owing to the inherent defects of the installation and misleading tests on the efficiency of treatment, as described above. This has resulted in the school authorities being misled and living under a sense of false security in believing that the water supply was being adequately safeguarded against contamination by means of the chlorination apparatus installed.

GENERAL SOURCES OF EXAGGERATED - MOOSE RIVER -

The Moose River drains a considerable area receiving the drainage from the Abitibi, Mattagami and other larger rivers. It is probable that some pollution enters the river and various tributaries. The pulp and paper mill at Kapuskasing is known to discharge sewage and industrial wastes into the river. Closer at hand are a number of small lumber camps upstream from the school which may introduce both fecal matter and garbage into the river. Such pollution would be such as to render the river water unsafe for drinking.

SEVERE SOURCES OF SEWAGE POLLUTION - MOOSE RIVER -

The closest and most serious source of sewage pollution affecting the quality of the school's supply is the drainage from the Mission's sewage system as will be described in more detail later. Septic tank effluent finds its way into the river only 300 feet from the water supply intake.

Deposits of garbage, tin cans, debris and refuse were found along the river bank fronting the settlement and are illustrated in an accompanying photograph. It was also noted that the majority of the Indian dwellings were without privies or other means of sewage disposal. Consequently the refuse deposits include fecal matter.

Dear Mr. Perrier:

During my recent visit to our Society's school at Moose Fort the Principal drew my attention to the advisability of having the following pupils at this institution removed either to the Chapleau School or to the new School about to be opened at Sioux Lookout.

(a) Gilbert Faries, admitted August 28, 1921, born March 26, 1916. Registered No. 4.
(b) Daisy Faries, admitted April 4, 1925, born May 18, 1918. Registered No. 018.
(c) Roderick McDonald, admitted July 2, 1922, born Nov. 25, 1915. Registered No. 8.

The mother of Gilbert and Daisy Faries, the Principal informs me, is a very immoral woman, having at least four illegitimate children, but she expressed the desire the last time the Principal saw her, that these two children should be moved to either one or the other of the above institutions.

With regard to Roderick McDonald, the teacher at our Moose Fort School, Mr. Waller, is strongly of the opinion that he will develop into a splendid man and may bring great credit to his race if offered better educational facilities than Moose Fort possesses.

Both he and the Principal were strongly of the opinion that all the three above children should be moved to one of the larger schools and I now write to recommend that they be transferred to the new school at Sioux Lookout. As Canon and Mrs. Griffin will be leaving Moose Fort early in August and proceeding first to Saskatoon on furlough before going to Ireland they would be able to escort these children.

Reverend Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 22nd ultimo, in which you advise that you have received an application for the discharge of Philip Sutherland, No. 14, from the Moose Factory Residential School. In reply I beg to say that, while the Indian Act only gives authority for retaining a pupil in the school until he reaches his sixteenth birthday, the Department is willing to pay grant for pupils in residential schools until they reach the age of eighteen years, as it is felt that it is in the best interests of both the school management and the children themselves to remain until that age. This is especially true in the case of girls, and the Principal and others interested in Indian education are expected to make every reasonable endeavour to this end.

I note, from your letter, that the father of Philip Sutherland states that the previous principal, Rev. Canon Griffin, promised to keep this boy in the Moose Factory School for three years only. If you feel that this promise was made, it might be well to carry it out in order that there might be no ill feeling engendered against the school. No such promises should, however, be made to Indian parents in the future.

On February 17th, 1928, Maggie Rickard, aged 13 last July Number 027 was given a bunch of keys by the Matron to unlock the door in the next room, which she did but also ran up to the dormitory and unlocked the door that separates the girls dormitory from the boys'. The Matron found the door unlocked shortly after the girls had gone to bed. Maggie denied that she unlocked it. She denied again the next morning until other girls were called then she admitted that she unlocked the door intending after the girls had gone to sleep to go into the boys' room. To avoid misunderstanding I asked the father and mother with Rev. Mr. Mark as interpreter to come and see and hear for themselves. The mother came alone and after seeing the place and hearing the confession she took her daughter home without my permission, although I assured her as far as I knew the Indian Department would advise dismissal of the girl. At present there is no magistrate and no policeman in the place. Owing to mail service I have not been able to write before.

I am now writing for advice regarding Maggie. I would recommend her dismissal, but something should be done to prevent the parents taking their children from the school without permission. I am informed it has been a common practice in the past.
