Sir,

Re: Truants from day school, Moose Factory, Ont.,
Sec. 10, S.S., Indian Act.

I have the honour to report that on the morning of
the 30th October, 1929, I received a note from S. Waller, Principal
of the Indian Residential School and Day School for Indians and
white children, to the effect that some of the day pupils were
attending school in a very haphazard manner.

I made a roundup of the offenders and interviewed
their parents. The parents I found had a very strange attitude
towards their children with regard to school attendance. If the
child said he did not want to go that was all there was to it.
They would not force the child or strap the child but were
perfectly willing for me to strap the child. If they did it their
child would hate them. I informed them that I had no intention
of strapping their children, and that they were the offenders
and not the children. I explained the contents of Sec. 10 S.S.4
of the Indian Act to them, and have posted a notice explaining
it fully, in the H.B.C. store.

I have not made separate cases of these offenders
as the laxity was pretty general, and parents very ignorant.
The parents of the next offender however will receive the usual
three days notice. Some of the offenders are half breed
children and do not come under the Indian Act. These have been
warned in a similar manner, as I have no knowledge of the Provincial Law in this respect.

I have the honour to be,
Sir,
Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

I shall be obliged if you will furnish me with an expression of your wish with regard to the boy Walter Richard of Albany who has been in attendance at our Moose Factory School and is now eighteen years of age. The Principal states that he talked this matter over with the Indian Agent, and was advised by him to have the boy returned to his home at Albany. The boy states that there is "absolutely nothing for him at Albany and wishes to stay here at Moose." When the Indian Agent left Moose for Albany on January 16th., the Principal asked him to take Walter with him, but he refused to do so. The Principal then approached the Revillon Freres about transportation, but that would mean a delay until navigation opens in the spring, and it would involve a cost of $25.00 as the boy would have to travel as a passenger, and his ticket would cost that sum. The Principal wrote to the father last autumn and asked him to come and take his son away, but the father did not come nor did he acknowledge the receipt of the Principal's letter.

As the boy is now eighteen years of age, it seems to me that the best thing to be done is to allow him to stay at the Moose Factory School, as a grant-earning pupil, until such time as he is able to secure some employment in the spring or early summer. The Principal is of the opinion that he could secure employment in the construction of the T. & N.O. Ry., and I beg to recommend that this arrangement be adopted. If you wish him returned to Albany, will your Department meet the cost of transportation? A definite ruling from your Department will be duly appreciated.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,

Dear Sir:

The following is an extract from a letter written on May 30th, 1931 by the Rev. P. A. Northam, our Church's missionary at St. Paul's Mission, Albany, James Bay, to the Rev. J. Blackburn, Principal of our Moose Factory School, and just received here:

"The Revillon Power boat and two scows leave here next week for Moose. I am seizing the opportunity to send over to Moose three or perhaps four children. It is an emergency case. One of our families here had a very unfortunate time. The mother and three big boys died and the father and the remaining five children were found in a starving condition by the man's brother. The woman had been dead nearly a month and the boys for a couple of weeks. The bodies were unburied as the survivors had little strength to do anything. As soon as this news was brought in here food was sent out to them, and arrangements were made to get them in by canoe as soon as a canoe could be taken along the coast. The children have picked up wonderfully, but the father is in poor shape. He will be unable to look after his little girls and a boy of about seven. The oldest girl is about 12 years.

I do not know if you have any vacancies in the school, but I feel sure that, in a case of emergency, you will do your best and accommodate them in some way until such times as you are likely to have older children leaving the School. You may rest content that this is a real case for special effort otherwise I would not be sending them to you without first having made arrangements to do so with you."
In view of the painfully distressing circumstances set forth in this communication, I do not see that Mr. Wortham could have taken any other action than the one, nor do I see that the Principal of our Moose Factory School can do otherwise than receive the children mentioned when they arrive, and admit them to our school as grant-earning pupils. The Principal states that clothing will be required at once for these children, and requests authority to buy it locally. This authority is being granted, with a request that the account be kept separate, and forwarded to me for submission to your Department. I shall be obliged, therefore, if you will approve the admission of these children to our school, and meet the cost of clothing and transportation when the accounts are submitted.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Field Secretary, R.I.O.C.
Ottawa, June 16th, 1931.

In further reference to your letter of the 4th instant, your No. 622, regarding the account for $21.60 from your Moose Factory Post, I have to say that it is now found this account was forwarded to the Department by the Missionary Society of the Church of England in Canada, Winnipeg, on the 5th of September last, and a cheque in payment, to the amount of $21.40, was sent to The Manager, Hudson's Bay Company, Moose Factory, Via Cochrane, Ont., on September 18th, last.

Two dresses at $1.19 each were supplied, a total of $2.38, while in the account the charge was $2.56, which accounts for the deduction of 20 cents in the account as rendered.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

P. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Fur Trade Commissioner,
Hudson's Bay Co.,
Winnipeg, Man.
Ottawa, March 5th, 1932.

Sir,

The Department is in receipt of the account which you recently submitted for payment of $75.00 to Revillon Freres in connection with the transportation of the Wynne children to the Moose Fort Indian Residential School. I understand that this expenditure was incurred previous to your appointment and, also, that it was a rather special case. Under these circumstances, the account is being paid. I would point out, however, that, in future, you should not authorize any expenditure for transportation to and from the Moose Fort or Albany Residential Schools without first receiving specific authority from the Department.

In the case of these two schools, it is considered that the parents should be able to arrange for the transportation of their children to and from the school without cost either to the Department or the school authorities.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Bupt. of Indian Education.

Dr. W. L. Tyer,
Indian Agent,
Moose Factory,
via Coral Rapids, Ont.

Ottawa, October 23rd, 1935.

Sir,

The Department finds it necessary to send back the September quarter return of the Moose Fort Indian Residential School.

As you are aware, the Department allows grant for 43 days' holidays and, when preparing the September quarter return, the Principal should request payment, in the case of those pupils who were in the school on June 30th, for the exact number of days each pupil is in residence during the September quarter plus the 43 days' holidays for which grant is allowed.

It would appear from the return that the majority of the children who were in the school on June 30th were also in residence for 44 days during the September quarter. If this is correct, the Principal should have asked grant for 87 days for each of these children, viz., 44 days in residence plus 43 days' holiday leave. If, however, the children were only in residence for one (1) day during the September quarter, the return submitted by the Principal is correct. However, as there is some doubt in the matter and the Department wishes to pay the school the grant to which it is entitled, the return is being sent back in order that you may review it and, if corrections are necessary, you should have these made.

The grant requested for the new pupils who entered the school during the quarter is correct as it is apparent from the information given under the heading "Date of entrance to school" that the Principal has only requested grant for these new pupils from the date of entrance to September 30th.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. Sutherland,
Acting Supt. of Indian Education.

Dear sir;

I have in school a pupil, John Wynne #35, who is an orphan. He has attained the age limit of 16 yrs, and should be discharged this summer. Up to the time of writing I have not been able to find a suitable home for him. I have talked the matter over with the local Indian Agent, Dr. Tyrer, and with his approval I am writing you for permission to keep him in the school until such time as I may be able to find a suitable home for the boy, or until he attains the age limit of 18 yrs.

Dear Sir,

In reply to your letter of Apr. 25th 1938-No-44-6-10, we had some correspondence about this girl last fall. Your final letter was Nov. 30th 1937-No-44-6-10.

This girl was taken to the hospital in Cochrane last fall by plane from Great Whale River for treatment for dog bite. After she got better it was not possible to send her home so we admitted her to the Res. School here on your authority. I explained to you that we would not be able to get the father's signature.

I had intended to keep this girl in the school for another year at least, but will see the parents this summer. If you have to have the parents signature will you please return the form to me and I will get it signed this month.

Yours truly,

Mr. Phelan
Indian Affairs,

Dear Sir,

In reply to your letter of April 22nd No-44-6-10.

When I visit Albany in July I will get the letter you ask for.

I might give you an outline of this case.

When I visited Albany last July (Mrs Williams husband had died during the winter) the Old Williams people and their sons were making it very nasty for the young widow claiming she killed her husband and all that sort of thing and in general were interfering with her affairs and wanting to take the children away from her.

I had them all up before me and told them that it had to stop, that the mother was in full charge of the children, even after that one of the boys beat the woman up so I had them in again and warned them not to let it happen again.

I understood at that time that the widow had been a Catholic before her marriage although she turned Protestant with her husband and had been so during their married life. It seemed to me that that was really the cause of a lot of the trouble—the Williams family thinking that now her husband was dead the widow was wanting to go back to the Catholic church and take the children with her—I told the Williams family that that was up to the mother.

I was very much surprised when she asked me to examine two of the children for the Moose school—as far as I know no pressure was brought to bear on her, but of course in spite of my warnings the Williams family may have.

I had no forms with me so I examined the children and told the mother I would send the forms for her to sign when I got back to Moose.

The forms were made out and given to the H.B.C. to send up to the Anglican mission at Albany for her to sign but were overlooked in the mail and did not go, when I discovered they had missed the last fall mail I sent them in to you.

If in the meantime the widow has decided she wants to be a catholic that is her privilege, but last summer her statement to me was that she was an anglican.
Ottawa,
May 18, 1938.

Dear Sir:

With reference to our letter of April 20 regarding certain application forms for children entering the Moose Fort Indian Residential School I wish to advise you that these have now been received.

In forwarding this statement you should certify on it that her decision has been reached without influence from any outside parties.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,

Dear Sir:

The Principal of our Moose Factory School has furnished me with a copy of your letter of the 23rd ultimo. (File No. not given) addressed to him, in which you authorize the discharge of three pupils, and request further information in connection with the applications for admission to this School of nine children from Rupert's House. In your letter you ask if there is any special reason why these children should receive institutional care, and state that it is not your Department's practice to approve the admission to Residential Schools of children from Agencies where Day Schools are operated, provided the parents are able to support them and have them attend such Day Schools.

From a copy of the Principal's reply to your letter on the 9th instant, I learn that "the parents of these children are away from the post approximately nine months of the year", and consequently are unable to receive much training in the local Day School.

Moreover, as they are a handicap and anxiety to their parents when hunting and trapping, and are very liable to suffer severely from exposure and undernourishment during the long and trying season, it would be greatly to their advantage, as well as to that of their parents, if they were placed in a Residential School.

As "every post about the Bay" is reported to me to have its Day School supported by the Department and as the Principal of our Moose Factory School states that he does not admit to his School children of "parents who spend the year..."

Dear Mr. Hoey:

Our Commission have received repeated requests for a number of the children at our Moose Factory School to be allowed to return to their homes during the summer holidays. As you will know, these children are recruited from various centres around the shores of James Bay, such as Albany, Rupert House and East Maine. The difficulty in acceding to their request lies in the lack of transportation during the holiday period.

So far as the children from Albany are concerned, it is the opinion of our Commission that the parents themselves might be able to spend part of the holiday period with their children at the school.

With regard to those from Rupert House and East Maine, it would seem that the only way for them to reach their homes and again return to the school would be for them to travel in the boat "Charles Stuart" which your Department has placed at the service of your local representative, Dr. Tyrer.

As I understand from the Rev. Principal Thompson that Dr. Tyrer will be paying treaty during that time at different centres around the Bay, I am writing for the specific purpose of ascertaining if you will grant him and the Principal authority for the children from these two centres to be taken home and brought back in the Government boat.

I commend this arrangement to your sympathetic
consideration, and sincerely trust that the authority requested may be granted.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Secretary of the Commission.
Ottawa,
April 13, 1940.

Reverend Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 4th instant with reference to transporting children from the Moose Fort Residential School to their homes for holidays this summer.

The Department has no objection to children from this school going home for holidays provided the parents arrange for their transportation or the school management wishes to pay for it. The Department, however, will not have any funds available for such purpose.

Regarding your suggestion that arrangements be made to use the Departmental boat for transporting children from the Moose Fort School, I feel that this would be difficult to arrange to the mutual satisfaction of all parties concerned. Besides, if such permission were granted similar requests would likely be received from other schools in your locality as well as at other points throughout the Dominion.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 6th instant I may say that your action in insisting on Anglican parents who are able to do so sending their children to the Moose Factory Day School rather than the residential school is approved.

However, in the case of Catholic Indian children, if their parents wish to send them to the Albany Residential School the Department cannot see any reason why they should be prevented from doing so.

It has always been our practice throughout Canada to permit parents whose religion is different from the religion under which the day school is operated to send their children to the nearest residential school conducted under their own religious auspices.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Dr. P. Moore,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. Mines & Resources,
Ottawa.

Dear Dr. Moore;

I have just returned from my extended holiday, and upon my arrival I find that the two children who were to come to us from the Lady Minto Hospital have not arrived.

On checking up I find that Daisy Wynne has returned to her home in Moosonee, and I am wondering if that is according to your wishes or if you desire her to come into the school. I shall await your reply before approaching the family. I shall be glad to have this girl come into the school, also the other girl, as well if it is according to your wishes. I have not been able to discover where the other girl is.

While we were in London we received the news of Dr. Tyer's passing. It came to us as a shock, although we had known for some time that Dr. Tyer was far from well.

If there is anything we can do to help carry on until a new agent arrives we shall be only too glad to do it. Please do not hesitate to call upon us.

May I take this opportunity of wishing you the Compliments of the Season.

Yours sincerely,

Gilbert Thompson
Ottawa, Ontario,
December 23, 1940.

Dear Doctor Brunet:

When I visited the Lady Minto Hospital at Cochrane in October, I believe there were two girls in the hospital, Daisy Wynne and Ellen Blacksmith, who, we thought, might be discharged to the Residential School at Moose Factory.

Daisy Wynne has been sent home, but I believe Ellen Blacksmith is still in hospital. If you think she is all right, we could arrange to have her given some special care in the School. I would be glad to hear from you on this subject.

Compliments of the Season.

Yours very truly,

P. E. Moore, M.D., D.P.M.,
Acting Superintendent of Medical Services.

L. E. Brunet, Esq., M.D.,
COCHRANE, Ontario.

N.W.
Ottawa, Ontario,
December 23, 1940.

Dear Mr. Thompson:

I have your letter of December 17. We were all greatly shocked at Doctor Tyrer's sudden death.

I do not know how soon we will be able to get a doctor up there to replace him. Your kind offer of assistance is greatly appreciated. I believe the Department has placed the R.C.M.P. Constable nominally in charge until a new Agent is appointed, but your kind cooperation will be appreciated.

I have written Miss Hadland regarding some patients in the hospital. I believe Daisy Wynne would be much better in the School if you can arrange to get her in. If you are ever given per capita grant, I will pay for her maintenance in the School from the Medical Vote.

The other girl was Ellen Blacksmith of Rupert's House. She, apparently, has been kept in the hospital at Cecchran. I shall write them regarding sending her to the School. If she is to be sent, we will let you know.

I would like to extend to you and your Staff Compliments of the Season.

Yours very truly,

P. E. Moore, M.D., D.P.H.,
Acting Superintendent of Medical Services.

The Rev. Gilbert Thompson, B.A., L.Th.,
Principal,
Bishop Horden Memorial Indian Residential School,

Dear Sir:

Enclosed please find an Application for Admission, of a boy into this school. You will note that the signature of the father is missing. It is impossible to get in touch with him at this time of the year.

The boy in question was placed in the school by his father July 11, 1939, and a proper complete application went in at that time. You will note that Dr. Orford considers him sufficiently improved to allow him to leave the hospital and it is upon his approval that this boy has been placed back in the school.

Dear Sir;

One of the pupils attending this school has successfully passed the Provincial Entrance Examinations, and is desirous of continuing with High School work. The person in question is, Andrew Faries. He is a boy of intelligence and ability, having passed his entrance at the age of 14 yrs.

The nearest residential school offering possibilities for attendance at a High School is Chapleau.

I fully realize the need for strict economy during these trying times, and would therefore suggest that, with your approval we would be glad to take care of this pupil for the first year or two if arrangements could be made for him to enroll as a pupil with the Provincial Correspondence Department.

Trusting that the above suggestions will meet with your approval. I am,

Yours sincerely,

Gilbert Thompson

Dear Mr. Hoey:

You will note from the following extract from a letter just received from the Rev. Gilbert Thompson, B.A., Principal of our Moose Factory School, that he desires some definite ruling with regard to circumstances under which Indian parents may have their children removed from a school into which they have duly admitted, and where they are expected to remain until they have attained the age limit for their discharge.

Mr. Thompson's letter was dated Moose Factory, Jan. 24th, and reads in part as follows:

"In this area parents apparently think they can take out their children whenever they please. The most recent instance occurred this week when the wife of Thomas Niekoshi asked for her children out of the school. She gave as her reason that since her husband had joined the army she needed the children home to help look after the smaller children while she helped her 16 yr. old boy to get wood. The two whom she wanted are girls, 12 yrs. and 14 yrs. respectively. I am fairly well convinced that the reason she gave was not the real one. I had a little trouble with the younger of the two girls and told her that if she could not behave better I would not let her stay in school. She went home and told her mother what I had said and her mother told her she would take her out of school. Before the mother came to see me she went to see the Agent telling him that she needed the girls home to help her and he said as far as he was concerned it would be alright for her to take them out, but that she had better come and see..."
I have let the children go since I could not see that I could do otherwise. Hence my reason for asking if there is any ruling on the matter. If there isn't would it be possible to obtain one from the Dept.?

I happen to know Thomas Nickoski and his wife, Clara, quite well. I also remember that, before our new and larger school was built at Moose Factory, some of their children were being educated in our Chapleau School. When the new school was ready at Moose Factory the two children that were at Chapleau were transferred to the Moose Factory School, and I learned from Mr. Thompson that these are the very children that the mother is now insisting on having at home with her. Mr. Thompson's statement that he is fairly well convinced the reason given by Mrs. Nickoski for wanting the children home was not the real one seems to me to indicate that we would be justified in asking that the case be very carefully reconsidered by the Indian Agent, and an order given for the children to be returned to the school, should it be found that they were allowed to leave for reasons which are not in accordance with the facts.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

TBEW*WS

Dear Doctor Westgate:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 3rd instant with reference to the communication you have received from the Principal of the Moose Port Indian Residential School. I am forwarding a copy of your letter to the Indian Agent and asking him for a report. On receipt of his reply you will be further advised.

In the meantime I may say that it has always been definitely understood that when a child is admitted to an Indian residential school such child should remain there until formally discharged by the Department. Such discharge is usually recommended either by the Principal or the Indian Agent and I believe, in most cases at least, both these officials concur before applying for discharge. With this in mind I am at a loss to understand why Mr. Thompson allowed the children to leave the school without making application to the Department.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoy,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Sir,

I have noted the contents of your letter and that of Dr. Westgate, which you attached.

Mr. Thompson's comments were rather a surprise to me, as he remarks that apparently parents in this area think they can take out their children whenever they please. This is the first instance to my knowledge where I have, in mutual agreement with Mr. Thompson, sanctioned the removal of children from residence - although the R.C.M.P. Police and myself have been approached on other occasions to interfere.

Mrs. Nickoshi came to complaining of treatment her children received at the school and demanded that they be allowed to go home and stay with her - also giving as an excuse that she needed the children to help her since her husband had joined the army. As the woman was quite hard to handle, I went to Mr. Thompson and discussed the matter with him and it seemed best to both of us to avoid further trouble by allowing the children to go out, provided they attended Day School. Mr. Thompson made the remark that he was not at all anxious for the children to return to Residential School, as he anticipated that if this was done their mother would continue to be a source of trouble.

In future any complaints will be discussed with Mr. Thompson and both sides of the matter referred to you for decision.

Yours truly,

Dr. T.J. Orford

Reverend Sir:

The June quarter return of the Moose Fort Residential School has just been received, and it is found that it has not been prepared in accordance with the instructions.

The number of boys and girls should be shown at the bottom of each sheet of the return and grand total on the last page. This applies also to the columns for "Class". It is not necessary to total the ages, but the age of each pupil should be shown. The date of entrance of each pupil to the school should also be entered in the column for that purpose.

Your kind attention to the above details will be very much appreciated and will ensure the earlier payment of the per capita allowance.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,

Dear Sir:

There are two children who did not return to Moose Residential school this year. They are with their parents at Island Falls Junction and at Kattice.

The parents in each case took their children home during the summer holidays with the expressed purpose of keeping them away from school.

Correspondence has been carried on with the parents advising them of the regulations concerning education and in both cases now they express willingness to have the children return to school but lack the funds for transportation.

Will you kindly advise me who would be responsible for expenses of the truant officer - Corporal W.G. Kerr - to return these children to school.

Dear Sir;

In view of the fact that I acknowledged your letter in which you asked that the services of the R.C.M.P. be not used unless absolutely necessary, I feel it my duty to report to you that I have had occasion to call upon the services of the local R.C.M.P.

On the evening of Nov. 20th., between 6.30 p.m. and 7.30 p.m., two boys left the school grounds. I began searching for them shortly afterwards. By 10.00 p.m. I could not locate these boys and knowing that they might have crossed the river, which crossing was precarious in the dark due to the fact that parts of the river were not yet frozen, I notified Cpl. W. Kerr of the R.C.M.P. Together we made a further search that night. The following morning I went to Moosonee and discovered that it was possible the lads had slept in the deserted shack of the family of one lad. No one had seen the boys at Moosonee. That night the policeman and I went across to the shack in the hope that the lads would have returned there, but they were not there. The next morning the policeman took his dogs and went down the railroad track following up a lead that someone had seen two people walking on the track, who had later disappeared into the bush when sighting the on-coming man. The boys were well clothed, but not outfitted for severe weather. Before the policeman overtook them they had walked some 24 miles and had reached the camp of the parents of one of the boys. All returned the following Wed. night by train, including the parents of the one boy. (The other boy comes from East Main and has no parents).

Sometime on Thur., the parents of the one boy went to see Dr. Orford, the local Indian Agent, when they asked to take the child out of school giving as their reason, as far as I can ascertain that day, that they were afraid the boy might run away again and get some other boy into serious trouble. The boys gave as their reason for running away that some of the boys teased them. They are 13 yrs and 14 yrs of age. On the Thur. afternoon the policeman came with the parents and said the Indian Agent, Dr. Orford, had given permission for the parents to take their boy, Mathew Chum, #110 out of school, but before doing so the father was to punish his boy in front of the other children. The boy left that afternoon.

In a letter to Dr. Westgate from Mr. Hoey, #44-6-10 relative to the discharge of pupils Mr. Hoey writes in part.
The Secretary, Indian Affairs Branch

Dec.1/43

"In the meantime I may say that it has always been definitely understood that when a child is admitted to an Indian Residential School such a child should remain there until formally discharged by the Department. I am at a loss to understand why Mr. Thompson allowed the children to leave the school without making application to the Department."

In the instance of this boy being taken out of school you will readily see that I had no opportunity of making application to the Department. I was simply told that the parents were to take the boy out and they waited for him.

The whole incident does not help us in trying to make the people realize that once they have put their children in school they should leave them there until they are 16 years of age. It will work the opposite. I anticipate other children leaving the school almost on any pretext and the possibility of the parents appearing to take their children out of school. Unless something definite is done about the matter I shall be at a loss to prevent them. I shall appreciate anything you might do to prevent such a situation.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

P.S. I am sending a copy to Dr. Alderwood for his information.

Ottawa,
December 7, 1943.

Dr. T.J. Orford, Indian Agent, Moose Factory, Ont.

The Department is in receipt of a letter dated the 1st instant from the Principal of the Moose Fort Indian Residential School in which he reports that two boys truanted from the school and were eventually located. In the case of one of the boys, namely, Matthew Chum, the Principal advises that soon after he was returned to the school the policeman came to the school with the parents and stated that you had given permission for the parents to take the boy home. The Principal allowed him to go.

As you are aware, when a pupil is placed in a school the permission of the Department must be obtained before discharge can be granted. This regulation is designed not only to preserve uniformity in the handling of the discharge of children but is also a great assistance to the individual Indian Agent, as it relieves him of a considerable responsibility. Of course, in making a decision we are guided by the recommendation made by the Agent, as it is presumed that he has consulted the Principal and that both of them are in agreement.

In this particular instance the Principal should not have allowed the boy to go until you had furnished him with a copy of our permission. However, the Principal's action at this time does not really affect the point at issue, which is that discharges must be approved by the Department. I should appreciate hearing from you in this matter.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Ottawa, December 6, 1943.

Dear Mr. Thompsons,

I have for acknowledgment your letter of November 17 and have noted with interest the somewhat disturbing information contained therein.

The officials of this Branch are heartily in agreement with you, that a worthwhile educational system cannot be established on the whims and caprices of an illiterate and prejudiced population. This expression of opinion applies to a great many white communities and it certainly applies to a great many of our Indian agencies. You can rest assured, there are, that we shall do everything humanly possible to co-operate with you in any attempts that may be made to change existing conditions. You ask why is not compulsory attendance enforced in Indian communities, the same as the provisions of the Public School Act in white communities. The answer to this question is very simple. Experience has taught us that where compulsion is exercised—and it has been exercised quite frequently throughout the years, in attempts to maintain regularity of attendance at Indian day and residential schools—the results have been invariably disappointing. Attempts on the part of the R.C.M.P. to enforce attendance have created an impression in the minds of a great many Indian parents that our residential schools are penal institutions, established, not for the benefit or education of their children, but to punish them. This feeling or attitude on the part of Indians has become so widespread that we have been recently asked by the Commissioner of the R.C.M.P., not to use his constables as truant officers and that, if we must use them, to use them sparingly. This antagonism on the part of Indians in certain cases has become so pronounced that we have had a suspicion on more than one occasion that the destruction of certain residential schools by fire was deliberate and not accidental. It is just possible that we may find a solution for this problem.

It is the remedy that first suggests itself to me when confronted with the problem of non-attendance, but I am not at all sure that it is the best remedy.

Re: Loose Fort Residential School

On November 20th two boys from this school, Matthew Chum and Luke Tomatuk, ran away and walked about 25 miles to the trapping camp of the father of the Chum boy. Corporal Kerr of the local police followed them by dog team, arrived by train of November 18th.

The parents of the runaway returned to Loose Victory with the boy and insisted on taking him out of school. This was the second time he had run away and they feared he would do it again and that he might be lost or frozen to death if he attempted it. The only alternative they offered was to remain at Loose Victory and neglect their trap lines.

In view of their opposition to having their son in school I came on this occasion for his future safety I could not do other than give consent for them to take him with them or they could have done so in any case. However, I did insist that they punish the boy themselves and not pass it on to others in the school and this they did willingly enough.

Truants from Bishop Horden Indian Residential School - Moose Factory, Ont. - Matthew Chum and Luke Tamituk.

1. At 9:15 P.M. of the 20th instant, Rev. G. Thompson of the Indian Residential School reported that two of the pupils were missing, Matthew Chum and Luke Tamituk.

2. After supper, the same evening, both the boys had requested permission to go to the lavatory outside the main building and had not returned after permission had been granted by the supervisor on duty. Matthew Chum had previously been guilty of truancy the preceding spring. Both boys were just under 14 years of age.

3. Accompanied by Mr. Thompson I patrolled the Island and made inquiries among the local residents but to no avail as neither of the boys had been seen. All vacant houses were visited. Later we followed the trail to Moosonee across the Island and where the trail goes onto the river ice we found no marks of anyone going in that direction. The tide at that time was high and the border of water around the shore made it impossible to reach the solid ice. Another route to Moosonee was investigated but no tracks seen on it. The barns and outbuildings of the school had also been searched.

4. The next day it was learned that the boys had slept in a cabin at Moosonee the previous night (The cabin was one belonging to Matthew Chum's father who was on his winter trapping). Indians interviewed reported they had not seen the boys and that they were no tracks on the railway leading south. A further search of the Moosonee district was made but no trace of the missing boys was found. Later in the evening an Indian Trapper who had been walking along the railway south of Moosonee and who had just reached the village, reported that he had seen two persons along the track but they had run into the bush before he could identify them. They had been proceeding south. He also reported that the tracks had reached the railway from a creek bed some two miles from Moosonee which would account for the absence of tracks along the regular path south.

5. Both the boys had been dressed in rubber boots and cloth windbreakers, and although Indians were camped at 12 mile intervals along the tracks, it was feared that a sudden cold spell might have serious results to the boys if they were caught between camps or met with any injury. Neither boy was believed to have matches or axe.

6. The next morning I set out alone with 4 dogs and sled along the tracks leading south. I expected to find the boys at the first Indian Camp but on my arrival there I learned they had passed there the previous afternoon. I continued on and while camped in the bush some 20 miles from Moosonee that evening, I was visited by an Indian returning to his...
6. - camp from his traps. He informed me that he had passed the boys the previous day and that they were headed for the camp of James Chum, father of Matthew. He stated that this camp was located off the tracks in the bush some 12 miles further on. I hired him as guide and set off within the hour and we travelled to midnight. The guide was a bit off in his computation of mileage and we camped with some Indians for the remainder of the night in the camp that the guide had thought was James Chum's. The next morning we set off again and around noon reached James Chum's camp where I found both truants, Matthew Chum and Luke Tamituk.

7. Both boys, on being questioned, stated that they had left school because the other boys had teased them and for no other reason. The father and mother of Matthew Chum informed me that they had intended to return the boys to school on the weekly train and that the boys had given them the same reason as given me for leaving school.

8. As my 4 dogs were incapable of transporting the boys, guide and myself back to Moose Cree through the prevalent deep snow and I had no camping equipment outside of an axe and canvas sheet, I decided to send the dogs back with the guide and return with the boys on the weekly train which could be flagged from the tracks.

9. I stayed at the camp until the following evening (24-11-43) and we flagged the train at 7:30 P.M. and arrived at Moose Cree the same evening, where I returned the boys to the school.

10. The next day James Chum and his wife applied to the Indian agent, Doctor T.J. Oxford, to have their son released from school as they were worried he might get into trouble sometime by running away and injuring himself or other boys he might take with him. The Indian Agent gave them permission to take the boy back to camp with them, and released him from school.

11. Disciplinary action was taken by the Principal of the school on Luke Tamituk, and Matthew Chum was spanked before the assembled boy pupils at the school by his father.

Dear Sir:

MARY SUTHERLAND
BEULAH MARK
DOROTHY VINCENT
CAROLINE MAANSKUM
JAMES CHEECHO

I might mention in the case of James Cheechoo that during his short stay with us he has made such worthwhile progress that I am asking the Missionary Society of our Church to cover his keep for another year's schooling. He is a good scholar and learning well in the manual training department and it is a shame that he was not able to attend school years ago.

Yours faithfully,

Henry G. Cook.

Dear Archdeacon Cook:

Ottawa, October 29, 1946.

Very Reverend Sir:

Attached hereto is your quarterly return for September, 1946. Also attached is our circular letter 150-87 dated the 29th of December, 1944, which we hope will assist you in compiling your quarterly return.

We would like to point out the following discrepancies in your September return:

1. You show only 30 days as the total number of days in the quarter whereas there are actually 92 days, as this quarter includes July, August and September.

2. A study of this circular letter will show you that 62 days' grant is allowed to cover the holiday period for all pupils who were in school at the end of the June quarter. It is presumed that the number of days shown as 30 in your return is incorrect and that 92 days should have been shown. This, of course, will make a great difference in the grant to your school.

3. Under the heading "Remarks as to progress, etc.," the required information should be shown opposite each pupil's name, and, if necessary, a general review covering the various reasons for absence may be included in a letter forwarded with the return.

4. You have shown the names of several pupils on your June return but have omitted these same students from your September return. From Item 2 above you will see that

Venerable Archdeacon H.O. Cook,
Principal, Indian Residential School,
Moose Factory, via Moosonee, Ontario.

........... 62 days'
62 days' grant is allowed for such children. However, the Department should be requested to approve the discharge of all pupils who have left the school and whose names have been removed from this return.

5. You should note on Form All (Admission and Discharge Form) the name and school number of each pupil admitted or discharged during the quarter. We have not yet received any such form from your school for the September quarter.

6. We would like to emphasize that where a pupil is absent from your school for any length of time, the date of departure from the school, the exact date of return and the reason for such absence should be shown opposite the pupil's name. This applies to pupils in the September return who were late in returning to school and for whom you have requested less than a 30 days' grant.

It is our sincere hope that the above remarks will act as a guide to you in the compilation of these returns. As you are aware, we have many residential schools, and as our grants are based directly upon pupil attendance, it is most important that we are given correct and accurate information in order that the cheques for such grants can be quickly issued.

Sincerely yours,

Bernard F. Henry,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

MEMORANDUM:

Dr. Falconer

You will recall that I discussed with you the other day the situation that has arisen at Moose Fort School. Please note the application forms under this memorandum.

I think you will agree that it is simply impossible to operate a residential school along proper lines if the agent persists in following the same course of action as Dr. Orford.

Philip Phelan
Chief, Training Division.
Ottawa, May 30th, 1947.

Dr. T.J. Orford, Indian Agent,
Moose Factory, via Moosonee, Ontario.

We are in receipt of the following application forms for children who have been placed in the Moose Fort Residential School,

Marion McLeod - 9 years of age
Alma Katapaituk - 5 years of age
Warion Katapaituk - 8 years of age
Sarah Sealhunter - 10 years of age
Iza Cheeso - 9 years of age
Freddie Blackned - 7 years of age
George Stewart - 11 years of age

The names of these children appear on the return of the Moose Fort School and grants requested for them. Due to their physical condition it is extremely doubtful if they can obtain any great benefit from the actual school training and, in addition, each of them knows that their stay in the school is strictly limited. Besides, it must cause a lot of extra trouble to the school staff. We were aware that the procedure adopted in this case had been done in the past, but only with the occasional case.

From an educational standpoint it would appear that we are operating a convalescent home. Is there no other provision that can be made for these children? Copy of this letter is being forwarded to the principal of the Moose Fort School.

Bernard F. Neary
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Moose Factory, Ont.
June 11th, 1947.

Mr. Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent,
Welfare & Training Service.

Dear Sirs—

Re: File 44-6-10(WT.1)

Reference is made to your letter of May 30th concerning certain children for whom Moose Fort school requests grants.

It is difficult to see what other provision could have been made for any of these children. There are no facilities here for boarding out that many and once they have recovered from illness it is not feasible for them to remain in hospital. It has been through the courtesy of the school Principal, Archdeacon H.G. Cook, that accommodation was found for them.

Each child was brought to Moose Factory for hospital treatment. In each case it was not possible to return them to their distant homes or I considered they should remain for further observation although such observation did not warrant their occupying hospital beds more urgently required for acutely ill patients.

With the exception of one child - Isa Cheezo - they are now in good health, thanks almost entirely to good food and care at the school. Aside from any other consideration it would have been inhuman to send them home or into the bush with local families, knowing full well they would not receive the care required.

Isa Cheezo has been returned to hospital as she developed Chorea.

I cannot suggest an alternative unless you could discuss the matter with Dr. Moore with a view to the Health Services making a grant for their maintenance. It would also be appreciated if the Dept. could advise me, what attitude I am to take in future similar cases.

Major Gen. G. R. Turner

Colonel B. F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Colonel Neary:

Transportation of Indian Children
to and from Residential Schools

Thank you for your letter of 30th October.

From the last paragraph I would infer that, if the situation warrants, under Sub-section 3 of Section 9 of the Indian Act you are prepared to assist with the transportation to and from the schools of children who return to their homes during the long summer holidays. Is this correct, please?

I appreciate that your funds for this service are limited and that you work on the basis of treating all residential schools fairly in the matter of allocation of such funds. We have had, however, an abnormal expenditure on transportation during the past summer of children attending our Moose Factory School because of the breakdown of our James Bay boat which necessitated sending the transmission to Toronto for complete overhaul and repair. In consequence, we were obliged to use aircraft to bring the children in from pointe along James Bay, which has been quite an expensive business. Do you feel that you could do something to help by accepting at least some of this transportation cost as a charge against your funds?

Yours truly,

G. R. Turner
for Superintendent

GRT/BP
Ottawa, November 17, 1947.

Dear General Turner:

Yours truly,

Bernard F. Neary,

May 11th, 1948

To The Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ont.

Your No. 44-6-10 (E1) May 7th, 1948

In reply, no doubt that Moose Fort has only a limited number of vacancies, if we take the children now at Chapleau and those becoming of school age, that we can easily get at, our share would be about 20 Protestant children, living on the railway line or working out from, for this year.

At Mistassini and Waswanipi, the Indians over previous trials and results, are not in the mood to part with their children as they say "to send them far away to be spoiled". From these two Bands, Protestant children there, now of school age about 200 children, I am satisfied if we had within the district a boarding school to take care, they would not object to send them, and more through various routes they would take them in themselves, it would be creating difficulties for the future, insisting that they send them now to Chapleau or Moose Fort, particularly at Mistassini they should be first interested into going to school through Summer Day School, or equal.

My personal opinion is, if there is space, the children living near or on the railway line scattered all over should have the first opportunity, for this class are almost under pressure now, if they wish to work in the near future, in any event it won't take many years this class will have to earn their living like whites.

I maintain also, the only solution to get results, children from the same Band should be kept as much as possible within others in the district, their nature definitely brings out fault finding with others and finally they start withdrawing children and cause all sorts of difficulties, we must keep in mind also that the Mistassini and Waswanipi Indians are more or less from James Bay, and they feel they are a class by themselves in any event, they will not approve sending them there, traditions will come in heavy on their views.

H. Lariviere - Supt., Ind. Agency.

To The Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ont.

Attention: Mr. L.J. Young, Chief, Education.

Further to various communications in connection with transportation from Mistassini to Moose Fort - children for the residential school. I first went at Mistassini for annual visit. It was understood with Rev. Ellis, it was not feasible to undertake moving children from Mistassini to Moose Fort at the present time, on account shortage of beds at these schools and there was on the railway lines, in Quebec as well as in northern Ontario and on the Canadian Pacific lines, a good number of children not attending schools at all and next trip would never have the opportunity to attend any kind of schools except a residential school, after discussing this with him, he definitely agreed, it was best thing to do, provide for those on the line and then there as we develop a population, penetrate into remote areas, nearest to transportation facilities.

After I left Mistassini, what took place I cannot say, however, the Principal at Moose Fort, communicated with his office, we did everything possible to gather the Indians on the line, excepting for the child hospitalized. All those of school age, applicants, went to Moose, on their own good will and parents escorting themselves.

Finally the request of Mr. Ellis reached us, which was out of understanding, next too late for the Indians at Mistassini to accept willingly and so on, when I visited Mistassini with Mr. Corn, Mr. Lewis in August 1948, I reviewed the children who had been chosen, in most cases, the parents objected and I did not find a good number, on account our records indicated the Indians, feeling minded and in some cases a little children were above school age, that is too old to learn anything, and naturally stupid "they could not register anything in a school" good only to do some work around place.

After having spent considerable time on this, I visited the Indians themselves with a good interpreter, the parents in most cases informed they had been told or forced or equal to let go their children, which was in some ways in the minds of these primitives, that we were taking away their children forever. After general review, taking into account our records, the following agreed on their own free will.
1. Ronnie Morrison
2. Other - not or dead
3. Father hospitalized
4. Other dead
5. Other dead

Above represented the list as fixed by you.

In view of the relocation of Mr. Morrison, I have made arrangements to have him transferred to an institution in Ontario, where he will be able to receive proper care and attention.

I am confident that this arrangement will prove beneficial to Mr. Morrison and his family.

Enclosed please find a copy of the report form for Mr. Morrison's case file.

Thank you for your cooperation in this matter.

Sincerely,

H. Lariviere - Supt. Ind. Agency.

Dictated but not personally signed because of absence from the office.
As regard transfers of Indian children on Moose Fort, in order to avoid complications, retain the good will of our PRIMITIVE and so on, at Mistassini it should be definitely arranged during ANNUAL VISIT, and the Indians would be able to adjust themselves, their supplies for coming winter, clothing etc., otherwise we upset them.

Teachers going into these areas have next to no idea or understanding of the reaction of these VERY PRIMITIVE and they cause on such matters nothing else but difficulties and they don't appear to take into consideration it is not an easy matter to provide transportation at a fair cost and so on, which means they pick up any families, without knowledge of their ability etc., endeavour to make them believe it is a good thing, etc., finally the Indians don't live up to their understandings and trouble gets started, more they have no knowledge of their medical records etc., most of the unfit are usually selected.

If at all possible, I would appreciate that selecting, etc., and providing children for residential schools be left entirely in the hands of the Agency, providing we know in advance how many they can take care, we will see that the wamnecles are taken up, I am most anxious to avoid complications and the sending of children to these schools that we know in advance won't stand up at all.

The Mistassini Burgomaster experience was one very costly and which upsetted the Indians very much, they are primitive and most cases very much so further they like to be pushed around, we have their good will and through good will I am satisfied we can get them to agree, on sending children out, they understand and know but putting on pressure, by saying you send this one and that one, they won't accept that.

I feel teachers in remote areas should be allowed transportation, this would overcome part of our troubles also.

My views on the whole matter is this, Rev. Elkins, made efforts to secure authority to transfer by plane, one group direct from Mistassini to Moose Cree, acting as escort himself, considering the number of children recommended in the first place, it was evident the next group was to be taken care of by Higginson, which met - escorting on their way out of Mistassini.

I have no objections to children from Mistassini going to Moose Fort, providing they can be taken care of, once there and that they don't prevent other children from going to school who are living in that area, for our Mistassini Indians, are still far inland and not urgently in need of that type of schooling, Waswanipi is in a greater need, also closer.
October 2nd, 1948

Attention: Mr. B.F. Neary, Supt. Education

Further to various communications in connection with transfers from Mistassini to Moose Fort - children for this residential school. First when at Mistassini for Annual Visit, it was understood with Rev. Ellis, it was not feasible to undertake moving children from Mistassini to Moose Fort at the present time, on account shortage of beds at these schools and there was on the railway lines, in Quebec as well as in Northern Ontario and on the T.N.& O. lines, a good number of children not attending schools at all and next they would never have the opportunity to attend any kind of schools, except a residential school, after discussing this with him, he definitely agreed, it was the best thing to do, provide for those on the line and from there as we develop accommodation, penetrate into remote areas, nearest to transportation facilities.

After I left Mistassini, what took place I cannot say, however the Principal at Moose Fort, communicated with this office, we made every effort possible to gather the Indians on the line, exception for one child, hospitalized, all those of school age, anglicans, went to Moose, on their own good will and parents escorting themselves.

Finally the request of Mr. Ellis reached us, which was out of understanding, next too late for the Indians at Mistassini to accept willingly and so on, when I visited Mistassini with Mr. Conn, Mrs Stevenson, on August 17th, I reviewed the children they had recommended, in most cases, the parents objected and I did also for a good number, on account our records indicated, T.B. infected, feeble minded and in some cases a waste of money, way above school age, that is too old to learn anything, and naturally stupid " they could not register anything in a school " good only to do some work around place.

After having spent considerable time on this, I visited the Indians themselves with a good interpreter, the parents in most cases informed they had been told or forced or equal to let go their children, which was in some ways in the mind of these primitives, that we were taking away their children by pressure, after general review, taking into account our records, the following agreed on their own free will to go...

Dear Colonel Neary:

Re: Mistassini Indian Children - your file 44-6-10 (F.I.)

I have just returned from a three weeks visit to a number of our western schools, and have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of October 28. I read with a good deal of interest the portion of Mr. Lariviere's letter quoted in your communication. The Administration most certainly will be glad to do all it can to co-operate in this matter of providing the Mistassini Indian children for Moose Factory School. However, our associations with Mr. Lariviere in the past have not always been satisfactory. In the minds of some of our missionaries is the certainty that he is hostile to our work, and my experience has been that he resents very much the work of the Church of England among the Indians in the Mistassini and Waswanipi areas.

Under the circumstances of past experience I feel that we would be most foolish to rely wholly upon the judgement of Mr. Lariviere as to how many and which children should attend the Moose Factory School. I beg to request that recommendations from missionaries and from the Administration receive your consideration as well as the recommendations of the aforementioned agent.

At the moment the Moose Factory school has 93 pupils. If Mr. Lariviere co-operated more with the missionary in the area during this past summer the pupilage at this school could quite easily have been brought up to the authorised number with hardly any more expense to the Church or Government.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Superintendent

Attention: Mr. B.F. Neary, Supt. Education

In reply, I feel I must note that these children stand as follows:

Jeannie Miansoom
Mary Do
Simon Do

The mother a widow, did not look after her kids at all, all summer, she was out at Lake Dods, finally brought back by us under Police escort.

Emma Cooper

Father a widower, took the bush and left the kid at Oskelano. Her father wanted commit suicide.

Charlotte Shecapio

Illegitimate - father said to be white from Chibougamau - mother an Indian, married to a feeble minded Indian; child came back from Chapleau with a fractured arm in plaster cast with request "look after it", other Indians cared for her - shelter in such cases.

John Mark

Mother a widow - extreme poverty, assisted by us regularly.

Wesley Shecapio

a step mother - sick woman.

Peter Nayassit

a step father - originally R.C. now said to be anglican - more or less rejected.

These kids came back most of them with nothing but the little clothes they had at Chapleau, after two months in bush living on the "Indian orphan ticket at large" I can assure you they were not presentable to any one, Mrs. McLeod the wife of the Manager of the Company, took an active part to wash them and clean them, before their departure to Moose Fort.
All these kids are fairly intelligent, unfortunately, having to put up with unusual conditions at home.

This class is a problem to all, however I am satisfied, the Indians realize more and more, that we are interested in the most unfortunate and year by year they are helping, amongst our primitives not many years ago this class, was considered as the "future slaves" and the conditions were in proportion with the idea, part of it was very visible on these children when I took the trouble to arrange that they return to school, more I am satisfied to say if I had not taken a very active part in it, they would have never went, for they are looked upon as a rule by the Indians as the "rejected" and no one cares much for them, it follows if not at school they are in hospitals.

H. Lariviere - Supt. Indian Agency.

Dear Sir,

Further to our children, at Boarding School, Moose Factory, I regret to bring your attention to the fact children who should have been directed on Ochilance River, where sent to Innerture, fortunately by "good luck" were not at Innerture and sent on to Ochilance River, Que., only one had a ticket for Ochilance, escort advised us, the others their tickets terminated at Innerture.

Reports from the school show, that we have girls Francis and Christine Frappé, hospitalized at Moosonee for T.B., also boy John Mathias Mark, the parents are somewhat upsetted and to clear the matter, we are anxious to have a definite medical report on their conditions. Our records indicate that Francis - not TB tested - Christine - test shows on Vollmer 1 plus, and John Mathias Mark - vaccinated - B.C., which test he was free of infection when tested, and it followed he was B.C.O vaccinated.

I understand these TB patients or ours, are not in a regular hospital for T.B. patients, I would appreciate that Medical Officer attending, advise for we could secure beds for them in Quebec, transportation - their conditions, most taken into account.

Yours very truly,

Dear Rev. Mr. Taylor,

I have yours of July 20th, 1949, informing that you can take over forty children from this Agency, this quota does not include children from this Agency, who remained with you for summer vacations for various reasons.

I communicated with our Mr. B.F. Henry, Supt. of Education and we will endeavour to transfer the children, to fill in space allowed to Abitibi Agency.

Children that will go in, selection will be based on our medical records, which means in the majority of cases children vaccinated already against smallpox, diphtheria, whooping cough, tetanus, typhoid & paratyphoid, or T.B., tested or vaccinated, briefly we have developed a method to protect our children at home or elsewhere, to limit possible and through this their health has improved a great deal. Like last year we will furnish you their standing - medical, I insist that no injections be given them, without our knowledge and based on information that we will furnish you, otherwise it will upset our records and cause children to suffer with shocks etc..

During last season, we had three definite T.B. active cases with you, we are of the opinion, this took place through contacts with active cases in the school, in any event the parents of our children were much upsetted over this and caused difficulties, in this Agency we have put up a hard battle to stop out T.B. and we have reached the stage that we fear for contamination through others, I am given assurance that all possible measure will be taken this year to correct.

Re: Moose Fort Indian Residential School

Reference is to your letter of August 10th regarding particularly Helen Heubon recently a pupil at Moose Fort Residential School and now hospitalized at Roberval.

It is noted that of 21 children who have attended that school, 4 are now active tuberculosis cases.

The Educational Survey Committee was impressed by the assistance you are giving to the medical authorities, who are directing an anti-tuberculosis drive in your Agency. They have suggested a study of the history of admissions and discharges from residential schools which serve the Indians of your agency, and this study is proceeding and will, I expect, involve consultation with those officials of the Indian Health Services who are particularly concerned with the Quebec and James Bay area.

The manifestations which you describe are not peculiar to your Agency, but occur elsewhere in Canada where over a really searching examination for tuberculosis by a physician is impracticable before the child leaves on the long journey to a
residential school. When an unexamined child arrives at a distant school, the attending physician sometimes finds it essential to keep the child under observation. Some cases, of course, deteriorate rapidly and no blame for those cases can rightly be attached to anyone.

Your No. 467-1 & 10 (E3) August 18th, 1949

Moose Fort Indian Residential School

I wish to thank you for yours. I am satisfied we will enjoy improvement. I do not wish to blame anyone for the conditions that prevailed last year at Moose, however in this Agency, through "Medical Services" we were allowed to establish our own method, and since the Agency has directed the service, we have established a complete follow-up method on T.B., as well as on general. To do so we had to put in a great deal of time and effort; however it is serving the purpose, that is it is the basis today for all our welfare, etc., and with it we placed ourselves to send to schools healthy and fully protected children; needless to say if we run across a new source of infection, within the territory, we attend to it ourselves; outside, we have to go through headquarters.

A good example of what can happen, most recently at Mistassini, on "blind" selection, I was presented with 24 kids for Residential School; after going over our records I rejected 17. Our quota was filled only with fully protected children and of correct ages, and we still have a good number of children of the same category, but could not provide for. Briefly, without "recorded history", we would have sent in about 17 kids not fit to attend school, this only at Mistassini.

I can assure you that if we had our own schools, we are in a strong position to fill them with healthy children of proper ages and our Indians will send them in. This year, I could have had over 100 only at Mistassini and Waswanipi, all in line with our preventive field services.

H. Lefebvre, Supt.
Abitibi Indian Agency.
I wish to thank you for yours. I am satisfied we will enjoy improvement. I do not wish to blame anyone for the conditions that prevailed last fall, however in this matter, it was a "school service." We were allowed to establish a school, and since we already had directed the service, we have established a complete follow-up system. As well as a record. Also so we had to put into effect all of this new effort, however it is via the purpose that it is to be used today for all our schools, etc., etc., etc., which has been done. We have sent to schools healthfully and fully educated children; needless to say if we had across a new source of learning within the territory, we attend to it ourselves; i.e., we have to do our best ourselves.

In conclusion, I will mention, I was pleased with the kind of substantial school, after all, over our heads. I mention that it is the first time with us, however, children are correct, etc., etc., still have a good number of children who are coming, but cannot get room for. Finally, what I said before, we shall have out in about 17 weeks, but it will be a good school only at intervals.

I can assure you that if we had no more schools, we are in a very position to fill them up. Luckily children of good ages and our Indians will see them in. This year, I could have had over 100 but I missed one or two, I, all in the winter, now, the field services.
I have just returned from a three-week visit to clear children (including only) of school who are not attending school next year.

Here in London, I have not been able to turn their children, so I am writing to you to take note of the following:

1. Many of them are still wearing "out of the house" clothing.

2. Some are not wearing any clothes at all.

3. Others are wearing clothes that are not suitable for the weather, such as thin trousers only, with rubber in their feet, to keep them dry.

On the straight of New York, Taylor recently wrote, I assured them this year it will be much better all around. Finally they agreed to let them go, but by Harry positively refused to return, but here he is again, refusing to go, but still there.

They also complained:

To me, and in presence of Nurse Brunet; I warned them not to complain if it was not correct or exact.

Harry, who came back last year, upon my arrival at Moose School, they took me out of the serre pants, gave me a pair of trousers - black overalls, and I never seen or got back my blue serre pants. They did the same thing to my brothers George and David, for their good behavior.
The parents, Mr. and Mrs. Christiana Anderson, were present, following a statement by Mr. Anderson as follows:

"I am inclined to believe, the fact Henry did not want to return to school, didn't say anything, however convinced he is in some sort to his statement, that it is true, I feel it should be brought to your attention, for it creates a poor feeling among the Indians, they spread these rumors, etc., their statement incorrect they should be definitely checked on it. In this case their statement is rather strong, Mr. and Mrs. Anderson called Mr. Clark at once during visit at La Barre, Mr. Clark took a picture of the well tanks which the woman brought out from the tent that lay behind, near the front of the School.

(a) Department of Nutrition surveys recommend diets and as far as we are able we try to follow them. I know if we gave the children only the food they like we'd experience adverse criticism from Indian Health Services.

(b) Fish, quantities to which the children of Mistassini and Waswanipi are accustomed, is not procurable at Moose. The fish just are not there.

By the use of this method, we have established a basis, for assisting Indians, placing relief in proper hands and making it work to achieve improvements, we also use it as our basis for hospitalizing sick Indians and advising hospital hospital now often refers to us for information also local doctors, as regard school it allows proper selection, that is done away with the blind method of selection, take a chance have him examine after and so on, finally force the school to accept an unhealthy child or a costly return home.

Taking a doctor in to Mistassini and Massawippi, to have children examined would cost about $1,000.00 and very likely we won't be able to get a doctor to go in whom wanted, next taking the kids out for examination, it would cost as much and who would look after them briefly with present method I feel it should give 100% satisfaction, all these costly delays and so on are avoided. Assuming a child requires on check at school medical care, it cost very little to have done on the spot. Our children being all vaccinated, T.B. tested and re-tested annually vaccinated and re-vaccinated against T.B., if they could be accepted our present method of selecting, I feel it would save all concerned lot of costly difficulties. In any event the group of kids sent out this year, taking in this area, and likely at most places same number of kids, whose ours would stand up high, on health etc., the staff at Moose when they saw them after long journey and tough travelling; were surprised to see such a fine lot of kids, best ever seen they said. Dear Mr. Taylor,

Attached hereto records, on vaccinations, our children, as they stood when they left for your school. This record, two copies sent you, when completed I would appreciate that one copy be returned to this office, so that we can complete and write up our PHARMACY RECORDS.

Under separate cover we are mailing you Vaccine, as used by us, by its use on our children it will avoid any possible complications, on smallpox, your local nurses can do with vaccine on hand, on small pox cases vaccinated they should be rechecked before recording, in case that they are not "positive".

Going over our record, you will find a certain number of children marked "positive" on BCG this means these children at one time were checked, and could not be vaccinated, on account they were positive on Volmer or PPD test, others with date - year only, they were BCG vaccinated or re-vaccinated. Under T.B., those who are marked, we have a positive definite proof, that a member in their families, were infected and died of T.B., others are blank, but in some cases they have a brother or sister suffering with T.B., or discharged as cured, if at any time the Medical Officer desired a report on any of them, we would be very pleased to furnish. According to this record, etc., only Jeannie Tamoum, is expected to not stand up, being a 3 plus, however with good care and food, she might develop a strong resistance and rebuild herself against T.B.

Thanking you in advance, nurses doing vaccination, all she has to do, is to fill in the "sign space" opposite each names, when left open.

Yours very truly,

H. Lariviere - Supt. Indian Agency

I wish to thank you for having taken the matter up with Rev. Cook. I note his remark as regard Indian Health Services, this service, I am sure will support fully, that our primitive Indian children be allowed plenty of fish and some bannock, otherwise these kids feel starved, the trouble starts on their return home etc., we know they are not starved, but nevertheless primitive Indian way of thinking about "food" is a matter that will take years to adjust next when these children return home, if they had too much "whiteman" food, once at home the parents have trouble with them.

H. Lariviere - Supt. Indian Agency
