enclosure
Following an outbreak of typhoid fever among the Indian children attending the Bishop Gordon Memorial Residential School, operated by The Church of England Mission, at Moose Factory, Ontario, the undersigned was requested by the Division of Indian Health Services to conduct a sanitary survey of the area and to assist the Medical Officer in determining, if possible, the cause of the outbreak and to recommend remedial measures in order to prevent a recurrence of such outbreaks.

Moose Factory Island is located in the estuary of the Moose River some twelve miles from James Bay and two miles south of Woodcreek, the end of rail. The Island is roughly oval in shape and has an area of 1,133.3 acres. It is fairly level, about 22 feet in elevation above mean sea level and covered with second growth, spruce, poplar, birch and willow.

The settled and inhabited area of the Island is situated along the southwest side, the chief buildings comprising the Anglican School, small hospital, Anglican Church, R.C.M.P. Detachment, Hudson's Bay Company Trading Post, Roman Catholic Church and some seventy-six (76) Indian dwellings. The resident white population is thirty-six (36) in addition to three hundred and eighty-four (384) Indians, which are variable in number as they come and go.

Attention was first given to making a careful investigation of the water supply and sewerage systems of the Anglican Mission, followed by a survey of the general sanitary conditions prevailing on this Island. In this connection it is desired to point out that general matters of sanitation on the Island would properly come under the supervision of the Health Department of the Province of Ontario, in which it is located. The environmental conditions directly affecting the health and welfare of the Indians could be considered a Federal responsibility.

The story of the development and progress of the epidemic, as recounted by the Medical Officer, may be briefly stated as follows: In August and September, Mr. Timney, employed by the School, became ill and was hospitalized at Cochrane. On September 20th, a resident pupil, Peter ________, became ill followed later by one of the girls on September 29th. Three (3) more girls became ill on October 1st. A short time later, the Archdeacon and Superintendent of the School, Mr. Cook, was sent to hospital at South Porcupine, being diagnosed and later confirmed on October 6th as suffering from typhoid fever. The previous cases were also confirmed as typhoid.

On this date certain prophylactic measures were put into effect by the Medical Officer. All drinking water on the Island was ordered to be boiled and excreta from the known typhoid patients was disinfected and buried in deep pits. Since that time one girl and two boys became ill with typhoid. No further cases have developed within the outside incubation period of thirty (30) days so that the preventive measures adopted have apparently been successful in stopping the progress of the epidemic.

In summary then, there are ten (10) patients hospitalized with typhoid, five (5) Indian girls, three (3) Indian boys, at the mission, Mr. Timney and Mr. Cook at other hospitals.

The Anglican Mission School has a staff of thirteen (13) with fifty-eight (58) resident pupils and twenty-five (25) day pupils. Following the outbreak of typhoid the day pupils were not allowed to attend school.
The school and auxiliary buildings stand at the end of the settlement. The source of water supply is the river, which is pumped and delivered under pressure to outlets in the Superintendent's residence and the foreman's residence. The flow varies between seven-hundred (700) and two-thousand (2,000) gallons per hour.

The intake and pumphouse are located at the River bend, south of the school building. The intake is located in a cross-channel of the river, the suction pipe being 1½" galvanized iron extending about 20 ft. above covered with 5 ft. of water at low tide. The thickness of ice during the winter varies from 3 to 4 ft., and there is usually some physical damage done to the intake during the spring break-up.

The pumping equipment comprises an electrically operated (110 D.C.) reciprocating plunger pump with a rated capacity of approximately 900 gallons per hour. This is housed in a concrete pit on top of the river bank. The discharge line is a cast-iron pipe which runs to a 120 gallon pressure tank situated in the school basement with taps and branches to the various buildings. The system is automatic in operation and has a pressure range between 45 and 75 pounds per square inch.

In 1943 a hypochlorinator was ordered to provide treatment of the water supply and was placed in operation early in 1944. The unit is a hydraulically operated one, type HWS, manufactured by Wallace and Tiernan Company (New York). This feeds a chlorine solution into the discharge pipe from the pressure tank. The hypochlorinator operates when the pump is running by means of a solenoid valve on the distribution line from the pressure side of the tank. The hypochlorinator is situated ahead of the tank, which is regarded as satisfactory since there is provided for contact with the disinfecting solution.

However, a careful study of the actual operation of the system disclosed there are several inherent defects in the present arrangement. One serious defect is the fact that the water pressure line operates in reverse rather than being piped directly from the pressure side of the tank. Water passes through a long loop of pipe, off which are taken all the main distribution outlets; the connection to the chlorinator is made at the end of the loop. When the pump was running and a tap was opened, it was noted that due to the drop in pressure occasioned by the opening of the small pipe there was frequently not enough pressure available to operate the mechanism of the chlorinator. This means that whenever water was drawn off during the pumping period, unchlorinated water was added to the tank. As this condition prevails quite frequently, it follows that only 50% of the water pumped from the river to the storage tank contains any chlorine solution.

At the writer's suggestion, the school board has considered making a pipe connection from the pressure tank directly to the chlorinator to ensure more positive action. In this connection it should be mentioned that an electrically operated hypochlorinator is provided which can be connected to the pump to ensure continuous contact.

The present method of determining the actual amount of chlorine present is much to be desired. At present, the only test used to determine the adequacy of chlorine in the water is to add a measured quantity of potassium iodide solution to a sample of water and observe the color, if free chlorine is present. The normal color standard for this test is that 0.5 mg/liter of chlorine will produce a blue color after five minutes contact.

Attention: Mr. B.F. Neary, Supt. Education

Re: Moose Fort School

As our children at this school, when Mr. G. visited us, he felt that probably they would have been home at an earlier date, in order to permit us to arrange combined service, I would appreciate knowing at your earliest possible convenience, the date on which we might expect these children or arrange their return.

If these kids were delayed at a place like Senneville, Oskelaneo, it would be a costly affair, outside of, we have not the staff to look after them, if at all possible, I desire to gather them at one point, Oskelaneo River and clear rapidly, at this point, on account hospital service, if needed we could put up a tent, have some of the Indians, their own relatives to look after for a day or two, weather has a say on this.

H. Lariviere - Supt. Indian Agency.
To The Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ont., 12054

Attention: Education Division
Refer Your File No. 467-10
Dated September 17th, 1950

Re: Admission and Certificate of Health

Referring to your instructions as regard Certificate of Health, we are not in a position to complete this at Band points or at Railway points, first we have not sufficient staff to take care of it and we cannot arrange for Doctors to do these examinations as required.

Last year we selected the children ourselves, basis health record of family, child and only those tested on T.B., and vaccinated on general and B.C.G. were sent out, on general we allowed from 2 doses subject to completion at school, so far I understand none of our children, new admissions on our selection were ill this winter on preventable diseases. If this method is satisfactory to you, it would help a great deal. To assist we could cover each child with an admission form as to Medical Certificates, the Doctor at school could complete. On our method of selecting, I am satisfied no difficulties should be experienced.

H. Lariviere, Supt. Indian Agency.

August 22, 1950

Cip., Education Division.

Moose Fort pupils stranded at Cochrane:

I have been on the telephone all evening trying to make some arrangement for the onward movement of these children, but I cannot get through to any of the following:

Mr. Mattiss at North Bay.
Bishop Penison at Schumacher.
Rev. J.S. Ford at Cochrane.
Austin Bissell at South Porcupine.

I had a conversation with Col. Reynolds of the O.N.R. at North Bay re the possibility of a special train from Cochrane to Moose Lake, but he said that nothing can move on that railroad.

I have the urge to make a fast auto ride into the area before the problem becomes further complicated, but gasoline may be scarce in that area.

It looks as if these children may have to depend on the resources of Cochrane until the next trains run. Their escorts are probably at Cochrane, too.

C.W. Clark

To The Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ont.

Re: Children for Moose Fort School

Further to, Mr. Clark phoned me, after calling you, all is clear and will adjust itself.

On the Mistassini kids, bad weather caused us difficulties, finally ending with 20 kids at Cochrane and 16 at Oskelance. Cochrane got excited (or desired a little publicity), at Cochrane, I am of the opinion it was no trouble to look after these 20 kids.

Those left at Oskelance (Okalancee was out of flour, bread, etc., when the strike came on) 16 kids, I removed by aircraft on Sunday, provided for at Amos, at hospital, nurse was 1/3 of the kids, the kids themselves had lot of fun out of all this.

Others are at home, that is 94 from Waswanipi and other points, as soon conditions return to normal they will moved by normal and usual means of transportation.

Had we not been caught with bad weather, all the Mistassini kids would have been landed at Moose Fort, on time, before the strike went into effect.

H. Lapierre - Capt. Indian Agency.
To The Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ont.

Re: Children for Moose Port School

Further to telephonic conversation, the following was done:

1.- Mr. Clark took care of the children at Cochrane - D and escort Miss. Midlige all at Moosonee now.

2.- Nurse at Oskelance, with 16 kids, had to be removed, on Amos, via Senneterre, this work was done combined with other Agency affairs.

3.- From Amos, we transferred to Moosonee, the 16 kids by air, one trip with permission from Department of Transport, to take number desired, providing we would not exceed maximum weight allowed for mileage to be done.

Above cleared all Mistassini children, the total cost won't exceed very much, the regular transportation.

Mr. Clark requested our aircraft to proceed to Nemaska, to take out via Senneterre a Mr. Jackman, Teacher, our aircraft landed at Nemaska, found party out fishing instead of standing by waiting. Pilot requested instructions, I advised to return to his base at once. He waited in view to locate, etc., but found he was away by about 15 miles, so it was useless to wait extra time. The Pilot had to make Waswanipi for the night, weather bad, Miss. Midlige returned with him, on an Agency combined trip Miss. Midlige was returned to Oskelance.

As regard the Waswanipi children, waiting at home, further to telephonic conversation, they will be sent out direct from Waswanipi to Moose Factory, from Senneterre to Waswanipi trip both ways, will be combined trip, medical etc., usual run. Department of Transport is being requested to authorize, on same condition as we did for the Mistassini kids. One trip only,

This will put us to-date fairly well,
as regard the La Sarre kids, a few at Okaianee, they will have to wait
until rail transport is resumed. Our quota for Mistassini - filled 36
kids, Waawaniipi 17, might send in only 16 depending on weight and authority
from D.O.T., on the line, we have sufficient kids, returning to complete

H. Lariviere - Supt. Indian Agency.
Air Transport for stranded pupils, Moose Fort Residential School.

On Friday morning, August 25, I visited the office of the Austin Airways in South Porcupine and contracted with the pilot in charge for two and one-half trips (Cochrane to Moose Fort and return) to handle the twenty children and escorts.

I escorted the first flight of children and was quite busy en route with air-sick children. Mrs. Farr supervisor F.C. Racicot accompanied another flight, and the original escort, Miss Eva Macdonald of Oskelano, also was flown to Moose Fort where she rode back to Amos in a plane that brought sixteen children from Amos. This plane may also have taken Mr. Jackman from Temiskwa to Amos.

On the last trip from Moose Fort to South Porcupine I brought out the two summer school teachers, Mr. Spurs and Miss McCaulle. Dr. Cosack of Health Services came out at the first opportunity.

We might have saved one trip by getting Air Transport Board authority to over-load the plane, but I thought you would prefer not to attract criticism of the handling of Indian children. Besides, telephone calls required special permission and I would have had to negotiate with a Toronto office.

In all 36 children were transported (20 from Cochrane and 16 from Amos). On the phone Mr. Dept. Lariviere told me he would defer sending the remaining 24 g his quota until the railroads are again operating.

C.A.T. Clark

Ottawa, November 18, 1950.

Dear Colonel Neary:

Re David Koomayuk, Disc No. K4-364, Eskimo age 15

In February, 1949, a fifteen year old Eskimo boy, David Koomayuk, was flown by mercy plane from Creswell Bay on Boothia Peninsula to the Dr. Charles Camsell Memorial Hospital in Edmonton suffering the loss of both feet from gangrene. Since then he has been fitted with artificial limbs and is now able to move around quite freely. During his stay in hospital he has been taking advantage of the educational opportunities provided, and has learned to talk English fairly fluently already. He has received considerable amount of publicity due to his rather extraordinary progress for he is considered particularly brilliant. He has started Grade 3 arithmetic and in his reading has almost completed his Grade 2 reader.

Unfortunately, a short time ago he contracted a slight case of tuberculosis, but this has been cleared up and Dr. Falconer advises that the boy will be ready for discharge about January 1, 1951.

I am attaching herewith a copy of a letter I am sending to Dr. Moore. In this you will notice that the suggestion has been made that David should be placed at Moose Factory in order that he can attend the school there and also have the benefit of the medical service available at the hospital. Furthermore, he would be in the company of other Eskimo people and would possibly have the opportunity to work into a job that he could handle satisfactorily.

Colonel B.F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Citizenship & Immigration,
Capitol Theatre Building,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6204, file 467-10, part 4)
Ottawa, November 18, 1950.

Dear Dr. Moore:

I have received a copy of Dr. Falconer's letter to you dated October 10 in which he advises that the above-named Eskimo boy, approximately fifteen years of age, should be ready for discharge about January 1, 1951. The question of David's immediate future was discussed between Mr. Bailey of this Administration and Dr. Falconer recently when it was learned that Dr. Falconer was not too anxious to see this boy return to the rigorous climate of the north too early. He suggested that it would be preferable for this young Eskimo to be placed in a residential school for the next year or two if possible close to a medical centre.

The problem of this boy's placement has been discussed with both Dr. Simpson and Dr. Procter, the latter of whom suggested that David might be sent to Moose Factory where he could attend school and be close to the hospital there. Furthermore, he might very well work himself into a reasonably good job either as an interpreter or clerk. At the same time being at the gateway to the Eastern Arctic, it might be easier to obtain a position for him in one of the Hudson's Bay Company posts if that became possible at a later date. Dr. Simpson has stated that he is in agreement with such a plan.

It would be appreciated if you would ask Dr. Falconer to discuss this matter with David and ascertain whether this plan would be agreeable to the boy. In the meantime, a copy of this letter will be sent to Colonel Neary, Indian Affairs Branch to determine whether some arrangement might be made at Moose Factory for him at the school.

Re: Admission of pupils to Residential School

The question of returning our children to their families was settled this morning following telephonic conversation with Mr. Clark.

As regard returning them to residential school, selecting etc., our quota, I would greatly appreciate hearing from you, if at all possible by first week in August. Our last arrangement was as follows:

1.- Selecting children - Based on our medical records, free of T.B. and fully protected against contagious diseases - preventable by vaccination - also of a certain degree of intelligence. This to be done by AGENCY.

This method has given best results - none of our kids died etc., since.

2.- Transport arrangement.

3.- Can the children return home every summer?

4.- The Residential school should favor us with results - Examination at end of year - indicate degree of intelligence, etc., for I feel a child cannot learn anything at school, it is useless to keep on sending him, when others could replace and do well.

At Mistassini and Massawippi, we have reached the stage now, only children of school age, about 7, are available, this class is well protected etc., considering number ready, we can select among the most promising kids.

Thanking you in advance, I am leaving today for Mistassini, to return Amos on about July 1st.

H. Lariviere - Dept. Indian Agency.

The Administration, each June, requires an annual report from each of its School Principals. The Rev. H. Seegmiller, Principal of the Moose Fort School, under the question "comments or suggestions re pupils" has answered as follows:

"Mr. H. Lariviere, the Superintendent of the Abitibi Agency has been most cooperative. He seems however, to have a tendency to give us a different group of children each year. This fills the school year down and does not give the promising children an opportunity of advancing as quickly as they should. Perhaps I.S.A. office could write to him at his office in Amos asking his assistance at consecutive schooling for the children from his Agency."

I have not written Mr. Lariviere but have given you Mr. Seegmiller's comments instead. They are, I think very practical and sensible and I've been wondering if anything can be done to have the same pupils returned to the school after the holidays rather than a large proportion of new ones. All Mr. Lariviere is doing on behalf of the Anglican children of the Mistassini-Wawanapi country is certainly appreciated and we are not complaining at all but just wondering if the main purpose of operating residential schools is not being somewhat defeated when pupils are frequently changed.

The Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ont.

Attention: Mr. P. Phelan, Dept. Education,

Attached hereto copy of a letter which speaks for itself.

I am taking advantage of the fact that our nurse is escorting child Roman Petawabano, of Mistassini, to the school, to bring about a definite check on our children taken care of at that point.

This year, it has been a proper mix-up. The Indians at Mistassini particularly delayed their departure for their trapping lands, which caused poor feeling, etc. At Kasawipi, the same difficulty was experienced, but it was not as serious. During summer it was understood with Bishop Clarke I would be given definite quota early in August, and date of admission to be definitely fixed. With that it would have been easy to arrange and cause no friction. We know nothing yet about the children who were returned to school; it follows we are running into complications, parents, family allowances, etc., etc. We understand the staff is changed at Moose Factory school. However, through our nurse, we hope to establish a definite record. On her return, copy of 'em, you.

H. Lévière - Superintendent
Abitibi Indian Agency.

Dear Major McKays:

I am enclosing the ten applications of Protestant children to the Fort George Roman Catholic Residential School to which I referred in my telephone conversation yesterday.

I have wired Mr. Allan as per the attached copy of telegram and in conversation with him today requested that he place as many as possible of these children in the Moose Fort Residential School.

Dear Mr. Matters:

Complying with request contained in your wire of Saturday, October 18th, I have to advise you as follows:

I discussed with Father Houle, on Tuesday morning, the question of transferring these children from the Fort George P.C. Residential School to Moose Fort. He stated that he had not received any word from the Bishop in this connection and would be contacting him in the evening. I explained to Father Houle that this was the wishes of the Department but I would be willing to detain my flight to Fort George for a day or so in the event that there may be any further developments. Not hearing from Father Houle by Saturday, I arranged for the trip to Fort George and left in the evening reaching Rupert House where I stopped over for the night. I arrived at Fort George at 12:35 Sunday morning and immediately made contact with Father Couture, presenting your wire regarding situation of the children now in his care. He informed me that he would not release these children without the authority of the Bishop and he also stated in any case they would not be able to return with me due to the fact that they were on a picnic. He further stated that he would only release the children on the authority of the Bishop or the parents of the children. Due to the fact that it was the close of the season and the pilot was afraid of being frozen in we had to return immediately without the children.

After my return here, Father Houle informed me that two of the children were in hospital and four had been returned to their parents at Fort George. The other 4 children belonging to Rupert House would be returned to their parents at Rupert House by plane or snowmobile. Father Houle advised me that he had
received this information from Father Couture through the Hudson Bay Co. radio and he would send me a letter of confirmation. To date I may advise that no confirmation has been received.

Yours truly,

Dear Doctor McKone,

ER-117 Matthew Saunders-Eskimo

This boy was admitted to the Naval Hospital in Halifax in October 1948 apparently suffering from the aftermaths of poliomyelitis. He was treated at the Polio Clinic of the Victoria General Hospital in Halifax and returned to the Naval Hospital where he has remained up until this time. His condition is now such that while apparently in a cast, he is able to get around and should be getting some schooling. However, this must be carried out where he can have the attention of a surgeon for his case about every three months. It was arranged some time ago that the boy should be admitted to the Indian Residential School at Shubenacadie but it appeared that there was not suitable accommodation for him there and it was subsequently decided that he should go to Moose Factory.

The Administrative arrangements are rather complicated in that this Eskimo boy, whose home is at Fort Chimo, is a responsibility so far as educational matters are concerned, of the Native Administration and they in turn have arranged with the Educational Division of the Indian Affairs Branch to have him admitted to a Residential School. We believe that all the administrative problems should be left in the hands of the Indian Affairs Branch and the school authorities but we must keep abreast of his medical condition, being prepared to change the cast as required or, if necessary, to have him seen by an Orthopedic surgeon. We do not have any case history on our file and if it would appear necessary to have such it will be necessary for you to communicate with the Principal Medical Officer of H.M.C.S. Stadacona, Halifax.

Yours very truly,

P.E. Moore, M.D., D.P.H.,
Director, Indian Health Services.

Dear Reverend Sir,

In connection with admission and discharge of Indian children attending Bishop Borden School, we find the admission date as fixed now is a cause of difficulties to all concerned. To solve the problem you suggest that the school close on June 15th and re-open on August 15th. I think this would be in line with the needs and prevailing conditions at Mistassini and Waswanipi, as it appears you cannot overcome the fact that the staff must have two months off, also the children.

I suggest that you discuss the matter with Reverend Bishop Clarke and Reverend Canon Cook, and if you can arrive at something definite refer the matter to the Superintendent of Education in Ottawa.

The Indians at Mistassini particularly must get on the move to return to their trapping lands by early August, and they cannot very well leave children with others trapping closer to Mistassini awaiting for transportation and so on. The same remark applies to Waswanipi, although here they can wait a few days, etc.

When at Mistassini and Waswanipi recently arrangements were made for children to return and be on hand for dates as called for by you. I might add the Indians at Mistassini were not too happy about it.
